text_segment: The battery management system (BMS) and electronic battery disconnect unit are described as components that monitor, manage, control, and disconnect the cells of a battery-electric or plug-in hybrid vehicle. The BMS includes a battery control unit plus multiple cell-supervision circuits; the disconnect unit can integrate the disconnect function, the BMS, and optionally cell-monitoring units as an all-in-one solution. The battery control unit measures cell voltage and battery current, controls contactors and pyro fuses, and provides vehicle interfaces via a 12-V supply with CAN, Ethernet, or other protocols. Cell-supervision circuits are scalable and can meet functional safety up to ASIL D; housing materials can be selected for balancing-current and cooling requirements.

Bosch describes its fourth-generation traction inverter as available in attached or integrated form and suitable for 400-V and 800-V architectures. With silicon-carbide (SiC) semiconductors, the page claims up to 99% efficiency, more than 50 kVA/L power density (over 100% higher than the prior generation), and up to 6% more range on vehicle level depending on the use case. SiC MOSFETs are said to cut total switching losses by roughly 50% versus Si IGBTs and to allow switching frequencies up to 24 kHz. Technical data lists 210–470 VDC / 360–920 VDC, AC peak currents 320–800 ARMS / 210–600 ARMS, peak power 50–250 kW / 100–350 kW, and continuous power up to 60% of peak.

Bosch eAxle systems combine an electric motor, power electronics, and a transmission into a compact drive unit for battery-electric vehicles and hybrid applications. The platform is presented with standardized modules and the choice of 3-in-1 or 6-in-1 variants, where the 6-in-1 concept places six components in a single system housing. The page lists scalable output of 70–300 kW, a 400-V / 800-V voltage range, and motor technologies including permanently excited synchronous machines and asynchronous machines. Bosch states efficiencies up to 93% in relevant driving cycles globally and links higher power density at up to 800 V to the use of silicon-carbide semiconductor technology.

Bosch presents a preintegrated heat-pump unit for electric vehicles that provides heating and cooling using propane refrigerant (R290). The module is intended to consolidate functions in one compact unit, lowering the complexity of the refrigerant circuit while offering scalable heating and cooling performance. Example uses include preconditioning or cooling a high-voltage battery and air-conditioning the vehicle interior. The page states the unit is available with one or two evaporators and that propane enables operation in both hot and cold climates, with cost advantages versus CO? systems. It also notes heating down to ambient temperatures of ?20 °C in heat-pump mode, helping avoid inefficient electric auxiliary heaters.

In Bosch’s brake-by-wire concept, electrical signal lines replace the mechanical connection between the brake pedal and the brake system. The system is described as consisting of a by-wire brake actuator and an ESP® unit, with the driver’s brake request transmitted through redundant signal lines; the two actuators are assigned to different channels of a redundant system. If a fault occurs, both actuators can build the required brake pressure on all four wheel brakes, and Bosch states this redundancy supports highly automated driving. The by-wire brake actuator implements the driver’s request and can be installed in different vehicle locations, adjusting hydraulic pressure with low energy consumption and providing high pressure build-up dynamics and positioning accuracy for blending electrical and hydraulic braking.

Bosch’s corner radar sensor is described as a surround sensor for advanced convenience and safety functions and for automated driving. The feature text highlights long range, wide beam angle, and strong angular resolution, and references a system-on-chip (SoC) design with a 3D waveguide. A proprietary chirp-sequence modulation approach is described as improving perception by extracting more detail from reflected signals, enabling detection of object position, relative speed, and direction of motion with very high accuracy. The technical data lists a 76–77 GHz frequency range, detection range up to 210/236 m, dimensions of 63 mm × 72 mm × 19 mm (without plug), and power consumption below 4 W.

The charger-converter is presented as a combined unit that integrates an on-board charger for the high-voltage battery and a high-voltage DC/DC converter that supplies the 12-V electrical system by converting energy from the high-voltage battery. Bosch attributes reduced packaging size to silicon-carbide technology enabling higher switching frequencies, and notes optional integration of vehicle charge communication unit functions. The technical data lists a 240–475 VDC high-voltage range, converter power of 2.4 kW at 14 V (forward), and interfaces including CAN(FD) plus CCS and ChaoJi. Charger ratings are given as 7.2 kW (1-ph, 2-ph) and 11 kW (1-ph, 3-ph), and firmware-over-the-air update support is stated.

For diesel powertrains, Bosch describes a common-rail system with piezo injectors designed for maximum injection pressures up to 2,700 bar. The system layout separates pressure generation from injection: a high-pressure pump supplies fuel at high pressure, and a rail on the engine serves as a high-pressure accumulator that distributes fuel to the injectors on each cylinder. Injection timing and injected quantity are calculated and controlled individually for each cylinder. Bosch states the piezo common-rail system can deliver up to ten injections per cycle. The page also mentions features such as DRS, intended to allow a smaller delay time between injections, and a new closed-loop control (NCC) that can reduce injection deviations by compensating for variables measured by sensors.

In non-automotive industrial hydraulics, Bosch Rexroth describes the Hägglunds Atom hydraulic motor as providing a maximum torque of 13.6 kNm for a hydraulic drive system. Because the motor can deliver full torque at its top speed of 400 rpm, the page derives a maximum power of 394 kW, and it lists a maximum pressure of 420 bar. The description adds that the motor mounts directly on the shaft in a compact design intended to withstand harsh environments. It also notes that a peak pressure of 420 bar helps it handle shock loads and cites applications such as shredder drive systems as examples of tough and unpredictable duties.

ZF states that its passenger-car inverter range covers applications from compact vehicles with about 100 kW traction drives and 400-V inverters through to higher-performance models using about 200 kW and 800-V inverters. For the 800-V class, the company highlights silicon-carbide based power electronics. The description frames the inverter portfolio as scalable across vehicle segments and voltage levels, matching different e-drive outputs without changing the overall supplier approach.

ZF describes AxTrax 2 as a fully electric axle for trucks built around an axle-based “one-box” concept intended to replace the engine, transmission and conventional axle when electrifying a commercial vehicle. The product description lists 210 kW continuous power and up to 26,000 Nm peak output torque. It also notes an integrated 800-V silicon-carbide inverter and a hairpin-wound electric machine, emphasizing power density and suitability for commercial-vehicle operating profiles.

ZF’s e-comp® Scroll is presented as an electric air compressor that provides compressed air for battery-electric and fuel-cell commercial vehicles. The factsheet emphasizes a scroll-based design and highlights oil-free operation. It also points to low noise and low vibration behavior, targeting applications where electrified drivetrains cannot rely on a conventional engine-driven compressor. The unit is positioned as a compact electrification component for supplying compressed air in electrified commercial vehicles.

ZF explains that its brake control solution for electric vehicles is intended to improve comfort and safety while optimizing the recovery of braking energy to extend driving range. The company states that the brake control supports driver-assistance functions such as automatic emergency braking and can be integrated into the vehicle’s electronic architecture via an optimized software interface. Technically, ZF describes the brake control as combining an electronic brake booster (EBB) with its latest generation EBC470 electronic stability control (ESC), covering vehicles from compact cars to SUVs and light commercial vehicles.

ZF describes cubiX® as a vehicle-motion control software platform that coordinates chassis actuators so the vehicle behaves as one harmonized system. In the start-of-production context, ZF says the software controls chassis functions to deliver harmonious acceleration and braking, precise steering, and balanced damping. The description adds that cubiX connects active and semi-active components through software and improves driving behavior by networking these units, coordinating multiple chassis subsystems via a unified control layer.

ZF describes ProAI as a high-performance controller suitable for different vehicle platforms, software applications and E/E architectures. In a performance-computing platform brief, the company highlights a new ProAI generation with a stated 66% increase in computing power while consuming up to 70% less power. The document positions ProAI as a core element of new vehicle electronic architectures, designed to cover a wide range of application fields for virtually all vehicle types.

ZF presents Smart Camera 6 as a front camera for ADAS and automated-driving functions that integrates an EyeQ6 processor. In an ADAS information package, ZF characterizes the camera with a 120-degree field of view and an 8-megapixel image sensor, described as more than four times the image resolution of the prior generation. The document frames these upgrades as enabling improved perception for safety functions and for meeting requirements associated with regulations and consumer-testing programs.

ZF presents the 8HP evo as an update to its benchmark eight-speed automatic transmission family and describes it as designed for a wide range of hybrid powertrain applications. The announcement frames the product as based on the established 8HP transmission while adding further developments intended to broaden applicability and improve efficiency. In this context, the transmission remains a stepped automatic but is positioned to integrate with electrified powertrains across multiple hybrid configurations.

ZF’s PowerLine is described in an English product flyer as an eight-speed automatic transmission for commercial and special-vehicle applications. The flyer lists concrete ratio data: with a torque converter, the ratios are shown from about 4.89 (6.5) down to about 0.64, and the stated ratio spread is 7.66 (10.2). The document links the eight ratios and wide spread to efficiency and driveability, aiming to cover demanding duty cycles with appropriate gearing across operating conditions.

ZF Wind Power describes customized gearbox designs for wind turbines covering outputs from roughly 1.5 MW up to 9.5 MW. The description states that the gearboxes can be configured with one or two planetary stages and one or two parallel gear stages. It also notes suitability for turbine concepts with three-point and four-point suspensions. The focus is on tailoring gearbox architecture and staging to the turbine class and support arrangement rather than on automotive vehicle applications.

Zone control units form the middle tier of the server-based electrical and electronic (E/E) architecture in software-defined vehicles. Between the levels of sensors and actuators as well as the high-performance computers, they redistribute the vehicle architecture and ensure the electronics interact smoothly across domains, reduce complexity and are the key to over-the-air software updates in the vehicle. One zone control unit bundles all electronic and electrical connections in a local section of the vehicle and is responsible for service and data management tasks in areas such as the front or rear. The zone control units are generally connected to the relevant high-performance computer via a powerful Ethernet link and are responsible for communication management and decentralized energy supply.

Continental is creating an entire “Road to Cloud” ecosystem for software-defined vehicles. The foundation is built on hardware and basic software to enable the complete infrastructure for computing and networking, and software solutions are paired with corresponding edge ECUs, sensors and actuators. With its high-performance computers (HPC) and zone control units (ZCU), Continental showcases scalable server-zone architecture solutions for all vehicle lines, from entry-level to premium. Continental demonstrates an AD-Cockpit HPC that integrates cluster, infotainment and advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS) features on a single system on chip (SoC).

Continental’s ARS 540 is the first production-ready 4D image radar and supports automated driving systems all the way from partial to full automation. While previous systems were only capable of capturing information on range, speed and azimuth angle, the ARS 540’s long-range radar sensor calculates an object’s location in addition to range, speed and azimuth angle also with its elevation to create a precise map of the driving environment up to 300 meters. The elevation measuring capability allows relatively small objects to be detected more precisely and provides high-resolution detail for object identification in adverse lighting and weather conditions.

The measurements were taken on a dynamometer test in accordance with the WLTP and were supervised by TÜV experts present. During each of three test runs, the vehicle with the MK C1 recovered 160 Wh of additional electrical energy on average in the deceleration phases of the individual cycle – around 32 percent more than the system in comparison. The MK C1 makes this possible by enabling consistent use of the electric motor as a generator during braking. The intelligent hybrid control can then use the additional electricity generated in this way for fuel-efficient driving, thereby reducing CO2 emissions and fuel consumption.

Continental states that it implements cyber security solutions on multiple levels and layers: on the first level, individual electronic system components are protected; on the second level, communication between in-vehicle systems is protected; on the third level, all external interfaces are protected; and on the fourth level, data processing outside the vehicle is protected against theft and manipulation. This level also includes cloud and backend solutions. The company adds that future products can contain cryptographic functions that can be used to introduce security keys, and that these keys are generated individually for each product so that even if one car is hacked, a second one is still protected.

Continental presents the Future Brake System (FBS) as a roadmap towards fully electro-mechanical braking. The company also presents the next generation of the integrated brake-by-wire system, which integrates the master cylinder, brake booster and control systems into a single compact and weight-saving module and reduces system weight by nearly 30 percent. Built upon multi-logic architecture, the system supports both distributed and centralized E/E architecture. Continental also showcases a sensor portfolio for electric vehicles, including a product family around high voltage current sensing and high voltage safety modules, as well as intelligent battery sensors and chassis position sensors.

Continental has developed a new technology for hybrid vehicles: the 48-volt high-power drive system with 30 kilowatts of output. This means it is now possible to drive even long distances purely with electric power for the first time. Previously, this was only possible using high-voltage drive systems – but not with 48-volt technology. Vehicle manufacturers can therefore offer new, attractively priced hybrid vehicles worldwide.

A small part with a major impact: EGT sensors significantly influence engine control. Continental is expanding its product range to include exhaust gas temperature sensors (EGT sensors) for the Volkswagen Group brands VW, Audi, Skoda and Seat and is also expanding its EGT sensor program for the Opel brand. The portfolio expansion includes forty-eight part numbers. The new sensors in OEM quality are available to order and can be delivered in sufficient quantities.

Tough mining applications call for Phoenix Phoenocord’s extreme durability and reliable performance in above and below ground use. The company highlights high dynamic efficiency, resistance to corrosion and low elongation. When it comes to high capacity and high breaking strength, Phoenix Phoenocord belts are rated from ST 5000 up to ST 10000. The product line is positioned for long-distance conveying where high capacity and high breaking strength are required.

Compact yet powerful, the EMR4 sets new benchmarks for power density, and its scalable architecture ensures top-level performance across applications. Depending on the configuration, the newly developed EMR4 axle drive delivers between 80 kW and 230 kW of power, with axle torque ranging from 1,700 Nm to 4,000 Nm. The scalability achieved is also clearly reflected in the module’s weight: depending on the required drive power, the mass ranges from just 45 kg to around 80 kg.

Schaeffler states that the performance characteristics of the inverter brick now being produced include increasing the maximum possible battery voltage to much more than the usual 800 V and achieving RMS currents of up to 650 A, turning the sub-module into a compact power pack. The company describes the frame-mounted sub-module as compact, efficient, and readily integrated into various inverters due to a modular and scalable design, enabled by an innovative silicon carbide (SiC) power semiconductor produced by partner ROHM, with the SiC chip drain-source voltage optimized according to OEM expectations.

Schaeffler describes a solution scope that includes coolant and refrigerant circuits with heat pump systems, ranging from efficiently and flexibly integrated individual components, via highly integrated thermal management systems, to complete drive concepts comprising the motor, transmission, power electronics, and thermal management as a single unit optimized in the system. The heat pump system is described as providing high efficiency with minimal space requirements, and a focus on the environmentally friendly and non-combustible coolant R744 is stated to future-proof this approach for automotive manufacturers.

With the so-called 4in1 electric axle, Schaeffler describes integrating the thermal management system as well as the electric motor, power electronics, and transmission into the axle drive, making the axle drive more compact and lighter. The company states that a new heat pump operated with the natural refrigerant carbon dioxide offers further efficiency benefits and that carbon dioxide has physical characteristics allowing more efficient heating and cooling of vehicles. Schaeffler states that an efficiency level of up to 96 percent is possible in an optimally designed system.

Schaeffler describes advancing steer-by-wire technologies with a force-feedback function in the Hand Wheel Actuator (HWA). The solution is described as combining a magnetorheological brake with an optimized BLDC motor to provide a precise steering feel while ensuring efficient energy use. This combination is described as significantly reducing the requirement for copper and rare earths compared to conventional steer-by-wire technologies, while also paving the way for innovative forms of vehicle control such as joystick steering.

Schaeffler describes future vehicle functions being consolidated into centralized and zonal controllers, reducing both vehicle architecture complexity and wiring effort. The company provides examples including Master Control Units (MCUs) and Zone Controller Units (ZCUs). The Zone Controller is described as a communications interface that manages, connects, and supplies control units, sensors, and actuators within a defined zone. The MCU is described as processing data for lateral and longitudinal acceleration, thermal and energy management, driving and charging strategies, and by-wire systems; based on a microprocessor, it supports the highest level of functional safety (ASIL-D) while ensuring secure communication.

Schaeffler states it has been producing high-voltage hybrid modules for installation between the engine and the transmission (P1 or P2) since 2018, and that a third generation module with integral converter has been in volume production since 2019. The module is described as usable with in-line powertrains in combination with automatic transmissions, transmitting up to 700 Nm of torque from the ICE and supplying 300 Nm from the electric motor. Schaeffler also states that a fourth generation 48 V P2 drive with integral power electronics is in development and is planned to go into volume production in 2025, with direct connection to the power electronics intended to minimize OEM integration effort.

Schaeffler states it will showcase an internal combustion engine demonstrator developed specifically for hybrid applications, featuring innovative damper solutions and electromechanical camshaft phasing units designed to meet future NVH requirements and emission standards. To further enhance emissions control when using decarbonized fuels, Schaeffler states it offers a Flex Fuel Sensor, which measures ethanol concentration and fuel temperature with a high degree of precision prior to injection.

Schaeffler states that cost-effective wind turbines require reliable components and describes producing bearing supports for wind turbines for over 30 years as a rolling bearing manufacturer and development partner. The wind sector page highlights an integrated concept for safety, including realistic tests on Schaeffler’s ASTRAIOS, innovative solutions for preventing white etching cracks (WEC), and high equipment availability due to condition monitoring. It also states that the rotor shaft bearing support is of central importance because wind-induced forces act there, and that rolling bearings are subjected to highly dynamic loads and operating conditions, with Schaeffler developing an efficient bearing support for each case in partnership with customers.

The company developed a bionic cooling-channel structure for a high-voltage battery cooling plate, inspired by natural patterns. This design is described as delivering 10% more cooling capacity with 20% lower pressure loss versus conventional flow. It targets lithium-ion batteries where cell temperature should not exceed 40°C for extended periods and where uniform cell temperature is critical. The coolant flow rate can be adjusted to actual demand, and the concept is described as reducing the temperature range by 50% while lowering peak temperatures. Material use is reduced by up to 15%.

MAHLE positions the electric air-conditioning compressor as a powertrain-relevant component in EVs because it supports thermal control of the battery, traction motors, and power electronics, affecting service life, charging speed, and range. The company states it has produced electric A/C compressors in series since 2019 and highlights high-voltage capability “above 400 V” plus large compressor strokes. It states its high-voltage compressor range reaches up to 900 V and up to 57 cm³ displacement, and attributes compact packaging to patented refrigerant cooling of the compressor motor and electronics.

MAHLE describes an integrated direct thermal management system that includes a heat pump function using multiple heat sources (including waste heat from the powertrain and ambient heat) to support winter efficiency. The company describes thermal management modules that control temperatures of the battery, vehicle interior, powertrain, and power electronics, and states the modules can increase EV range by up to 20% and improve charging speed. It describes combining components such as an electric compressor, heat exchanger, refrigerant valves, and others into a single unit, and notes one module is highly integrated by connecting the refrigerant circuit with coolant circuits.

MAHLE describes the “SCT” (Superior Continuous Torque) electric motor as designed for sustained high-performance operation over an unlimited period. It states the motor’s continuous output is 90% of peak power while remaining compact and lightweight. The company attributes the ability to operate under extremely high load for long periods to an integrated oil-cooling system that dissipates generated heat so the motor stays within an optimal temperature range; it also notes the thermal system can use waste heat to heat the vehicle. Applications are described across passenger cars, commercial vehicles, and off-highway machines such as construction machinery and tractors.

MAHLE describes an inductive, contactless charging concept using two pads (ground and vehicle underbody), each with a coil; the ground coil generates a magnetic field using 85 kHz alternating current, inducing voltage in the receiver coil and charging the vehicle battery via power electronics. It describes typical vertical gaps of 14–21 cm and states alignment is enabled by DIPS (Differential Inductive Positioning System), described as positioning accuracy of ~1 cm and enabling ?92% transmission efficiency. The company states SAE International selected the MAHLE system as a global standard solution (summer 2024) and describes integrated safety functions that can interrupt energy transfer if a living creature approaches.

MAHLE chargeBIG (described as a MAHLE subsidiary) presents smallBOX wallboxes in two versions: ECO up to 7.4 kW and PRO up to 22 kW. To reduce wallbox size, the company describes relocating intelligence and electronic components into a central charging hub called chargeCLUSTER. It states chargeCLUSTER can manage 2 (size S), 6 (size M), or up to 36 (size L) charging points, and that the centralized approach supports dynamic load management and compliance with legal calibration requirements for billing. Charging sessions are described as activatable via the chargeBIG app, eRoaming apps, or via a terminal using RFID/debit/credit card.

The MAHLE chargeBIG 6 system is described as a central control unit (“charging distributor”) with up to 6 three-phase charging points using permanently attached cable and Type 2 plug, available at 11 kW and 22 kW. The distributor is described as containing charge-control electronics plus residual current protection and overvoltage protection, and as meeting IEC 61851-1 and being CE compliant. Electrical data listed includes 230/400 V supply and network types (TT/TN/TNS/TNCS), IP65 protection for the distributor, and charge-point operating temperatures down to ?25°C. Load management is described as central for 1–6 charge points with configurable total phase current settings.

MAHLE states that steel pistons are coated with graphite to improve running-in characteristics and that the coating is largely worn away during engine run-in, so it is not included when specifying piston diameter. The document explains that coating thickness is approximately 0.015–0.020 mm, meaning a new piston measured with a micrometer can appear ~0.03–0.04 mm larger than the dimension specified on the piston crown. It notes pistons are supplied ready-to-assemble with mounted piston rings and describes determining cylinder diameter by combining the piston diameter and fitting clearance values specified on the crown (example calculation provided).

MAHLE explains that modifying the piston ring gap clearance of the second ring can increase contact pressure against the cylinder wall because much of the contact pressure is generated by combustion pressure behind the rings. The document states increased clearance allows pressure to reach the ring groove and behind the ring more quickly, improving scraping and sealing. It discusses piston ring set 081 RS 00105 0N0 (mainly used in BMW engines), noting databases may specify 0.3–0.45 mm, while the “real” clearance is described as 0.7–0.9 mm due to an OEM change in original parts, and MAHLE aligning aftermarket OE sets accordingly.

MAHLE is described as entering the market for stationary battery storage systems with a first series order for a cooling module. The press information frames the product as intended for steady-state storage applications and describes MAHLE drawing on in-house expertise to develop cooling modules for stationary battery storage systems. The same communication describes these storage solutions as used for power-grid provision and stabilization and for intermediate storage of electricity (e.g., from renewable sources), positioning the offering outside the core vehicle domain as an industrial/energy application example.

The company’s VCU, developed in-house, is described as serving as the heart of an electric drivetrain. This central control unit is responsible for controlling vehicle dynamics by providing and supervising the driver’s commands to the motor and the high-voltage battery. The VCU supports advanced vehicle dynamics by distributing torque between the front and rear axles and supports different charging standards. It also includes thermal management for high-voltage components and can be driven by a number of different bus systems.

High-voltage battery development and testing is described as being provided “from a single source,” with the company developing, integrating, and validating high-voltage batteries from feasibility to SOP. The company defines the cells and models and creates the electric, cooling, and housing design. State-of-the-art tools are used to conduct thermal, stiffness, durability, and crash simulations. In addition, the company conducts DV/PV testing as well as crash and EOL testing in dedicated facilities.

Charging solutions are described as focusing on the entire user charging experience, with the company positioned as an experienced partner for this scope. The company supports customers throughout the entire development process. Its engineers develop smart charging functions (such as Plug & Charge, V2X or WEVC) and integrate them into the complete vehicle. The company’s HMI departments can supply tailormade operating concepts for charging to support the intended customer experience.

For ADAS integration, the company is described as covering the spectrum from step-by-step planning for the complete vehicle and Advanced Driver Assistance Systems through benchmarking, requirement management, and system supplier management, followed by complete integration of software and hardware. Testing and validation are described as being performed both virtually and on test benches (hardware-in-the-loop) in early development, and with the vehicle on test tracks and public roads.

Virtual sensor integration is described as requiring close alignment with the styling department when integrating ADAS sensors into the complete vehicle. Virtual methods, such as the company’s Sensor Integration Tool, are described as helping balance optimal sensor positions with desired styling from an early development phase. ADAS features are described as essential for consumer ratings and vehicle homologation, requiring thorough complete-vehicle testing. The company plans and conducts ADAS tests and post-processing of test data, using its in-house test track or cooperating with external facilities.

In body-in-white, the company states it can manufacture the complete range of bodies, covering steel constructions, multi-material structural bodies, and all-aluminum models. Digitalized and flexible automation solutions are described as ensuring short integration times, including when changes are made to existing body-in-white production processes. The company describes using state-of-the-art technology and an array of virtual tools, including simulations, to integrate new products faster than before.

For multi-material mix and joining technologies, reducing global CO2 emissions is described as requiring optimization of how materials are used and processed in automotive manufacturing. Cutting emissions while also cutting costs is described as requiring new technologies for creating bonds between fundamentally dissimilar materials, including between metals (steel, aluminum, magnesium, etc.) and other materials (including hybrid materials or polymer reinforced metals). It also includes bonds between metals and surface coatings such as Alodine on aluminum or zinc on steel.

The company describes its services as spanning complete vehicle development, systems and modules, complete vehicle engineering, and complete vehicle production with flexible solutions from niche to volume production. It states more than four million vehicles have rolled off the production line to date, and that 37 different models for 13 different OEMs have been produced. Magna Steyr is described as the first vehicle contract manufacturer to produce a wide range of powertrain technologies in a single plant (from conventional drives to plug-in hybrids and all-electric vehicles) sometimes even on the same production line.

For aerospace, propellant lines for launch vehicles are described as needing to withstand extreme operating environments, where design and manufacturing standards are critical. The company states it has worked with cryogenic propellant lines since the 1990s and, as a development and manufacturing partner for the Ariane 5 program, played an active role in that launch-vehicle program. It describes delivering products ranging from small, high-pressure helium lines to large-diameter feed lines for liquid hydrogen (LH2) and liquid oxygen (LOX), made from stainless steel, nickel-based alloys, aluminum, and titanium, supported by welding and non-destructive inspection processes.

Battery trays sit at the core of electric vehicles and have to satisfy demanding requirements, including mechanical loads, efficient packaging, battery temperature control, sealing/tightness, and crash safety. In a crash, the tray must help prevent the battery from endangering occupants. BENTELER states it has produced battery trays for many years, with the first tray built in 2014 at its Jablonec (Czech Republic) plant. For current concepts, the company notes that many trays use extruded aluminum profiles with many joints, and it highlights options such as swivel bending and press-hardened sheet-steel crash reinforcements.

For battery trays, BENTELER describes alternatives to designs based on extruded aluminum profiles. It notes that sheet-metal solutions can be attractive, while steel is presented as advantageous for cost and carbon footprint and, in some cases, fire protection; stainless steel is cited as an option to avoid painting large components. Because profile-based carriers require many sealed joints, the company describes deep-drawn concepts to reduce joints and references a swivel-bending approach that requires only a few joints. It also emphasizes that joining methods and surface pretreatment matter for strength and sealing, and it describes testing welded and sealed folded-box concepts to meet fatigue requirements while maintaining the seal.

BENTELER describes a fully modular battery pack intended to be integrated into an electric vehicle’s body. The pack is described as comprising an aluminum tray, cooling, battery modules, and hardware such as fittings plus high-voltage cabling and connections. The company also points to a battery cooling system designed for vertically arranged cylindrical cells; the cooling elements are described as only a few millimeters thick in order to save installation space.

Within its Thermal & Tubular portfolio, BENTELER states that it supplies fluid and air pipe solutions as well as exhaust manifolds, and it also offers waste-heat-recovery solutions for combustion engines alongside solutions for hybrid and electric vehicles. For electrified applications, the company describes producing battery cooling plates using an innovative, patented “Press Brazing” process. It states that this approach combines reduced wall thickness with optimized strength and that the Press Brazing process uses 100% green electricity.

On vehicle structures, BENTELER states it is already in serial production as a tier-one supplier of battery storage systems for electric vehicles and that it addresses relevant customer and legal requirements for rechargeable energy storage systems. It offers aluminum, steel, and multi-material designs; for aluminum concepts, it notes a preference for 6xxx-series alloy profiles. The reasons given include weight reduction, safety, tightness, and modularity.

For chassis hardware, BENTELER reports annual production of more than 14 million control arms, links, and knuckles, ranging from simple to complex designs. It states these parts are made from steel and aluminum and are used across many axle concepts. The company adds that ultra-high-strength steel grades (up to 1000 MPa) are formed into safety-relevant chassis components. For extruded aluminum control arms (e.g., spring control arms), BENTELER describes using a stretch-bending process, enabling weight reduction of up to 35% and up to 50% higher stiffness versus conventional materials.

For electrified powertrains, BENTELER notes that making rotor shafts from tube reduces material use and therefore weight, which it links to vehicle-range benefits for electric vehicles. It states that rotor shafts manufactured from welded or seamless precision steel tubes are lightweight and robust, including at speeds up to 30,000 rpm. Beyond semi-finished tube-based parts, BENTELER also describes providing customized complete solutions for rotor-shaft components that are durable and cost-efficient.

In its fuel-system portfolio, BENTELER describes stainless-steel injection/manifold rails that are suitable for injection pressures in excess of 350 bar. It states that a unique, fully automated machining concept completes all machining operations in a single clamping. The company also indicates it offers fully automated fuel module assembly for piezo injectors, and that this assembly includes a complex sealing package.

For exhaust gas recirculation (EGR), BENTELER describes itself as one of the world’s leading suppliers of EGR systems and presents itself as a full-service provider from concept through series production. It states that its EGR products incorporate high-performance cooling with stainless-steel construction. The company further describes an optimized internal geometry intended to maximize heat transfer and highlights high thermal durability for high-performance applications.

BENTELER Steel/Tube describes HYRESIST® as seamless tubes intended for hydrogen distribution networks, and it states the tubes exceed European Industrial Gases Association (EIGA) requirements for line pipe in distribution networks. It highlights hydrogen resistance at temperatures from ?40 to +175 °C within a pressure range of 10–210 bar, plus weldability and heat-treatment-driven homogeneous material properties. The document also states compliance with API 5L and ISO 3183, and it lists (for HFS) 38.0–141.3 mm outside diameter with 4.0–16.0 mm wall thickness, alongside specified steel grades and PSL2.

The Webasto Standard Battery Pro 40 is specified with dimensions of 960 × 687 × 302 mm and a dry weight of 297 kg. Installed energy is ~40 kWh with 116 Ah nominal capacity and a voltage range of 333–407 V. Energy density is ~232 Wh/l and >135 Wh/kg. Continuous power (at 25 °C, SoC dependent) is listed as 45 kW for charging and 55 kW for discharging; peak power (10 s) is 60 kW (CH) and 112 kW (DCH). The cell type is prismatic NMC and operating temperature is -30 °C to +55 °C.

The Vehicle Interface Box (VIB) is presented as the main control unit for the Webasto Standardized Battery System, combining power distribution, a master BMS function and fuses in one housing. It is described as enabling connection of up to 10 Standard Battery Systems at 400 V or 800 V. Technical data lists 548 × 686 × 155 mm dimensions, 42 kg weight, 12/24 V LV supply, and 400/800 V HV supply. Stated limits include scalable power up to 460 kW, continuous discharge current 380 A, continuous charge current (OBC) 67 A, and continuous DC fast charging current 200 A, with operation from -40 to +85 °C.

Webasto’s electrical Battery Thermal Management (eBTM) is described as a plug-and-play device for thermal management of water-cooled traction batteries, including cell preconditioning during charging or before vehicle use, and compatibility with Webasto battery systems and customer-specific developments. Product specifications list dimensions of 1000 × 700 × 300 mm and a weight of 91 kg. Cooling capacity is specified up to 8 kW and heating capacity up to 10 kW, with a voltage range of 400 and 800 V DC. Refrigerant is listed as R-1234yf, and a 50/50 water-glycol mixture is specified for battery temperature control.

Webasto describes its High Voltage Heaters as using a thin heating layer bonded to a heat exchanger with a large contact area to achieve very fast heat-up and high efficiency, with temperature and heat output steplessly adjustable. Service life is stated as 15,000–25,000 heating hours. The HVH 100 Compact footprint is given as 284 × 200 × 72 mm, with stated weights of 2.2 and 2.5 kg; rare earths are not used. The heaters support 12/24 V low voltage and heat in a 250–880 V high-voltage range, delivering 10 and 12 kW. Control is via LIN bus (and CAN for some variants), with CE/ECE certification and active discharge support below 60 V.

Webasto states that it has integrated static and extendable lidar modules in cars and has also developed complete roof modules containing several sensor technologies such as camera, radar and lidar. The company describes a compact sensor strip in which various sensors and functions for sensor availability are integrated, transmitting signals and environmental information to the vehicle control unit. To keep detection systems functional, Webasto combines sensor solutions with automated cleaning and thermal management. Functions named include cleaning, de-icing and defogging, as well as sensor cooling, intended to maintain sensor availability in a wide range of weather conditions; different sensors are combined in the RSM depending on customer requirements

Webasto describes the Webasto Unite wallbox as a charging solution for business customers with charging capacity scalable up to 22 kW. Local load management is stated as preventing load peaks and network overloads, and the wallbox is described as supporting stand-alone and cluster mode operation. The unit is stated to comply with the Measurement Instruments Directive (MID), and it is described as featuring DC residual current protection plus integration into energy management systems. Webasto Unite is described as controllable via Webasto ChargeConnect (app or web portal), enabling remote start/stop of charging sessions. Authentication methods listed include the app, RFID, or Scan & Charge, and the wallbox is described as always online with 24/7 data transmission for transparency, control, and billing exports.

Thermo Top Evo is specified as a Webasto water heater with an evaporator burner and ECE approvals for heating (R122) and EMC (R10). Maximum heating capacity is listed as 5.0 kW (and 4.0 kW variants are also shown), with minimum heating capacity values including 2.8 kW and 2.5 kW/1.8 kW depending on variant. Fuels listed include gasoline E0–E10 (EN 228), E85 (DIN 51625), diesel B7 (EN 590) and DIN EN 15940. Rated voltage is 12 V with a 10–16.5 V operating range. Fuel consumption examples include 0.620 l/h at 5 kW and 0.310 l/h at 2.5 kW (with 0.22 l/h at 1.8 kW for the RV variant). The heater dimensions are listed as 218 × 91 × 147 mm and weight as 2.2 kg.

Webasto’s BlueCool S-Series (marine air-conditioners) lists cooling capacity from 6,000 to 27,000 BTU/h (1.8–7.9 kW) and integrated heating via a reverse circuit. Nominal voltage options are specified as 115 V or 230 V, with 50/60 Hz frequency. The specification table lists dimensions and weights by model: for 230 V units, S6 and S8 are 405 × 320 × 305 mm at 20 kg, S10 is 480 × 335 × 315 mm at 22 kg, S16 is 550 × 350 × 370 mm at 31 kg, and S27 is 575 × 515 × 410 mm at 46 kg. For 115 V units, examples include S6 at 405 × 320 × 300 mm and 18 kg, and S16 at 550 × 340 × 370 mm and 29 kg.

The charging harness is the charging cable set that provides the electrical connection from the charging socket to the high-voltage storage system. It transmits the energy from the outside of the vehicle (e.g. wallbox) to the battery inside the vehicle and can be shielded or unshielded. The charging harness can be used to charge the battery with both alternating current and direct current for fast charging (AC/DC). The cable cross-sections range from 35 mm² to 150 mm² and enable charging currents of up to 1,000 amperes.

The battery junction box (BJB) establishes the connection and also the resolution of the connection between the vehicle's high-voltage system and the AC/DC charging components. The main tasks of the battery junction box include changing, securing and distributing the high-voltage power from the power distribution units to the high-voltage battery. The housing of the BJB is usually made of plastic or metal. The main components include busbars, cables, fuses, screws and relays. The operating voltage is up to 400/800V and the operating currents are up to 500 amps; intelligent BJBs also have integrated controllers with a LIN/CAN interface.

The module & device connectors establish the power connection between the battery modules and HV units. These connectors are located inside the high-voltage battery and are part of the signal and power distribution system. Each product has two interfaces, which are equipped with either plug-in or screw solutions. Depending on the requirements, unshielded standard HV cables, braided cables, busbars or a combination of several technologies can be used as the cable material.

LEONI Hivocar® Cool is described as a state-of-the-art solution specially developed for the requirements of electromobility. These liquidcooled high-voltage cables provide a significantly higher current carrying capacity compared to uncooled standard HV cables with the same temperature rise. The portfolio ranges from 16 to 150 mm², whereby the diameter can be reduced by up to 30% and the weight by up to 75% compared to an HV cable with a comparable current carrying capacity.

LEONI High Power Charging (HPC) cables are described as enabling drivers to charge electric vehicles within a few minutes and to travel significantly longer distances. Such cables must have a smaller diameter to make them easy to handle, but this exposes them to overheating; therefore they are fitted with a liquid-cooling system. LEONI also describes developing a special HPC cable for liquid-cooled charging systems so that the temperatures in the cable and on the connector do not exceed a set limit.

The highlight of LIMEVERSE is described as a special insulation material developed by the company’s engineers that increasingly uses bio-based materials from sustainable and/or renewable raw materials instead of crude oil, verifiable using biocarbon in the ASTM D6866 standard test method. The text also describes mass-balanced plastics whose synthesis reduces the need for petroleum-based raw materials. The result is stated as a CO? footprint around 50% lower than conventional vehicle and charging cables (depending on cable type). The product line includes PVC compounds as well as polypropylene (PP) and TPE-U, enabling temperatures up to 125 °C.

Round, square or rectangular solid wires made of copper or aluminium are described as ideal for electric motors due to outstanding electrical properties, high dielectric strength and excellent mechanical integrity. LEONI exMW® is described as being available in flat, rectangular and round shaped profiles, allowing use in both radial and axial flux motor windings. In addition, LEONI describes exMW as winding wires manufactured by extrusion, enabling a uniform insulation layer without varnish or additional intermediate layers; this is stated to result in high production speed and precise control of dimensions and the insulation layer.

The International Test Laboratory (ITL) is described as performing tests on development and serial cables, including determination of mechanical, electrical and radio frequency properties, plus fire testing, environmental simulation and mechanical stress tests. Measurement possibilities listed for radio-frequency tests include mutual capacitance, bus capacitance, dielectric properties (eps_r, tan ?), insertion loss, input impedance, far end crosstalk, near end crosstalk, return loss, screening attenuation, voltage standing wave ratio (VSWR), unbalance attenuation (LCL, TCL, LCTL, TCTL) and characteristic impedance using propagation delay-capacitance, open-short and TDR methods.

The vehicle’s main wiring harness is described as connecting several control units and lights, actuators, motors and switches, consisting of cables ranging from 0.13 mm² to 16 mm² and more, as well as connectors with corresponding contacts and seals, wires, plastic ducts and grommets. The engine compartment is described as exposed to high temperatures, wet and corrosive conditions and, in some cases, heavy impact from debris, requiring electrical systems to be particularly robust. The engine wiring harness, carrying critical electrical cables to and from the engine, is therefore described as designed for ruggedness in every respect.

The extruded flat cables LEONI exFC® are described as consisting of several flat copper wires arranged in parallel and insulated with materials; special flat cables for lighting are described as using halogen free insulation. Listed application areas include energy bus systems, electrical window/door systems, lighting systems and ambient assisted living. For building services engineering, the text describes rising safety requirements and the need for high temperature resistant cables that must guarantee error-free operation even in the case of fire. The company describes developing and making such cables especially for lighting, heating and air conditioning systems, fire alarm systems, building safety and building management.

DRÄXLMAIER states that it has continuously expanded its expertise and product range for alternative drives and matching equipment since 2009. With 800-volt technologies, the company targets very short charging times. It describes battery systems spanning 48-volt to 800-volt, with integration that is independent of the cell type. Pouch, round, and prismatic cells are all referenced, and the storage systems are presented as relying on a fine-tuned interaction of system components optimized for performance.

DRÄXLMAIER describes developing, manufacturing, and supplying vehicle-specific wiring harnesses and complete wiring systems with electrical and electronic components for systems across all voltage ranges. It also describes “battery electronics” aimed at energy efficiency, reliability, and safety, to control and optimize energy flow along high-voltage paths. In addition, a modular high-voltage charging system is described that runs from charging socket to high-voltage double rail to high-voltage plug, linking the battery and infrastructure for integrated high-voltage supply.

DRÄXLMAIER describes a validation center for high-voltage battery systems at its Vilsbiburg headquarters, using facilities and technologies for testing and validation of high-voltage battery systems and components, on an area of around 3,000 m². For endurance testing, it describes operation under extreme climatic conditions with stated facility parameters: a 21 m³ climate chamber, test temperatures from ?48 °C to +120 °C (up to ±5 K/min), relative humidity up to 95%, and electrical operation up to 1 MW (1200 A/1200 V) with temporary overload capability.

DRÄXLMAIER describes the dFUSE smart HV as an electronic fuse developed for customer-specific current and voltage requirements in high-voltage electrical systems, intended to increase the reliability of safety-relevant system functions. The text states that faulty high-voltage paths can be switched off within microseconds, and explicitly refers to both 400-volt and 800-volt electrical systems. It also indicates that the dFUSE smart HV can be applied in an auxiliary unit and in the charging path, configured to automaker requirements, and mentions functions such as load monitoring as an added benefit.

DRÄXLMAIER states that it continually optimizes wiring harnesses by adjusting topology and architecture, including reductions in wire number, wire length, and cross-sections, and by using weight-optimized materials to reduce overall electrical-system weight. It describes a shift from many individual wires toward zonal architectures, supported by an “intelligent distributor” called the DRÄXLMAIER 12-volt power interface. The company states that this interface is designed in accordance with ISO 26262 for high safety requirements, and that protection is implemented electronically and via software-defined fusing.

In its press information, DRÄXLMAIER describes supplying premium automobile manufacturers with complex wiring harness systems, central electrical and electronic components, exclusive interiors, and battery systems for electric mobility. It positions itself as the inventor of the customer-specific wiring harness and states that wiring harness technology and electrical/electronic components are developed in-house. Examples listed include multi-voltage and high-voltage wiring harness systems, battery management systems, and intelligent power distributors. It also references solutions for low-voltage and high-voltage battery systems in the context of emission-free mobility.

A DRÄXLMAIER sustainability brochure describes material approaches for interiors, including the use of visible natural fibers as premium surfaces and processing recycled plastics, combined with resource-efficient processes such as in-place joining and a patented D3F (DRÄXLMAIER Fast Fiber Forming) method to save material and reduce weight. For an instrument-panel “display composite substrate,” it states that magnesium die-casting was replaced by long glass fiber-reinforced plastic (ABS LGF). It further states that, with the new raw materials and lower part weight, about a 90% CO²e reduction can be achieved compared with magnesium die-casting.

DRÄXLMAIER’s press information describes early automotive supply activity starting in 1958, stating that the company’s first order was to manufacture 50,000 wiring harnesses for the Goggomobil produced by Hans Glas GmbH in Dingolfing. It notes that a second product division followed soon after, supplying interior parts such as instrument panels, door panels, seat covers and rear window shelves for the microcar. The document also states that in 1960 the company introduced high-frequency welding for door panels and vacuum forming of thermoplastic film for instrument panels, which it describes as the basis for later process know-how in interior systems.

In a historical milestone entry, DRÄXLMAIER’s press information states that in 2009 the company received an order for high-voltage wiring harness systems for various Mercedes-Benz and Smart models. The same passage explicitly mentions that these models included battery drives, hybrid technology, plug-in hybrids, and future fuel cell drives. It characterizes this as an initial success in electrical mobility and states that the company would continue its involvement in this area with further innovative developments and products.

An efficient energy storage device is described as a key piece of technology for sustainable electric vehicles. ElringKlinger offers complete lithium-ion battery storage systems and modules for drives and auxiliary power units, as well as various individual components. The major advantage stated is that ElringKlinger offers development and prototype construction through to testing and series production from a single source. One of ElringKlinger’s core areas of expertise is combining a variety of different components reliably into a single assembly, acting as a development partner and supplier of both individual components and complete systems.

ElringKlinger states that its specifically matched cell contacting systems in various configuration levels can be placed and welded directly onto the cell composite. The plastic carrier frame accommodates the cell connectors and ensures that they can be installed in all tolerance positions. In addition to the already integrated voltage and temperature sensors, the monitoring electronics (CSC) can also be installed. Automotive plug systems or screw connectors can be used for the electrical connection outside.

Pressure equalizing units are described as compensating for pressure differences in the storage housing (e.g., when driving up and down mountains, with temperature differences, and for air transport in aircraft cargo holds without pressure equalization). The units are described as featuring an integrated safety function for critical excess pressure. The integrated emergency degassing function is stated to ensure rapid, controlled pressure equalization in the event of battery cell outgassing.

Plastic battery housing and modules are described as enabling weight and cost reduction, reduced installation work, integrated functions with a reduced number of components, optimized NVH properties, low thermal conductivity, and excellent electrical insulation. For Battery Housing / Component Protection ElroForm™ E (e.g., battery housing and module housing), the carrier layer is described as providing structural strength and rigidity, while also enabling weight and cost reduction and integration of functions, with optimized NVH properties.

The underbody protection for battery systems is described as needing to reliably withstand roadside impact loads and offer outstanding thermal and acoustic insulation. ElroSafe™ components made of thermoplastic fiber composites are described as offering crucial advantages compared with conventional aluminum battery bases. ElroSafe™ advantages listed include a high degree of strength, rigidity and toughness; low density and low wall thickness; high damage tolerance and heat resistance (fuel-fire test, thermal propagation); electrical insulation; and recyclability. The material system is also described as applicable to other lightweight applications such as bulkheads and rear bumper brackets.

Metal-elastomer gaskets are described as being used for highly stressed components such as electric drive units, battery storage systems, or engine and transmission components. They consist of a metal carrier with vulcanized elastomer profiles. The elastomer materials used are described as being developed in-house by ElringKlinger and tailored to the relevant requirements. Thanks to state-of-the-art process technology and injection molding technologies, different materials can be joined to a metal or plastic carrier, which is stated to enable the optimal material to be used for every medium to be sealed.

MetaloSeal™ is described as a sealing system based on metallic carrier materials onto which an elastomer function coating is applied; metal beads ensure line pressing that concentrates sealing force where required. Adaptability is described as a key advantage, combining different metals with different elastomer types aligned to the application, with high elasticity and minimal assembly forces. The latest development is described as an electrically conductive coating used in particular for EDUs and battery applications with high requirements for electromagnetic shielding (EMC). Temperature ranges from -40 °C to +800 °C and pressures up to 200 bar are stated, and installation in the main load gasket is described as enabling a simplified sealing flange design without a groove.

With the metal layer sealing system, engine components are described as being flexibly pre-tensioned around the combustion chamber via a deformation limiter (stopper). This is stated to reduce sealing gap vibrations caused by ignition pressure and prevent excessive deformation of the full beads. ElringKlinger states it offers technologies for deformation limiters including stamped stoppers (with stamps in the function layers, such as meanders and dimples, and in the carrier plate, such as diamond shapes), as well as laser-welded stoppers, folded-over stopper layers, and segment stoppers. Metaloflex™ cylinder-head gaskets are described as consisting of beaded, elastomer-coated spring steel layers (single or multi-layer), with a modular design (coating, bead and stopper) enabling tailoring to the relevant engine.

Metal-elastomer cylinder-head gaskets are described as mainly used in commercial vehicle engines and large engines (power plants, ships). Challenges listed include higher combustion pressures, compression homogenization, greater thermal loads and increased emissions requirements. ElringKlinger states its metal-elastomer system provides completely reliable sealing even in ignition pressures up to 290 bar, engine outputs over 2,000 kW and engine running times of 1.5 million kilometers. It also states that high ignition pressure on engines without bushings or with slip-fit bushings, low screw forces and a low number of screws can be managed reliably with pressing homogenization; for gas sealing, special steel-bead constructions are used to achieve an evenly high sealing pressure, while liquid sealing takes place via elastomer sealing lips at significantly lower sealing pressure levels.

For bipolar plates for electrolysis stacks, ElringKlinger describes automated series processes in metalworking and plastic injection moulding, joining and coating technology, and experience in PEM fuel cell stack production as enabling industrialization of bipolar plates with or without integrated gaskets. The company states its subsidiary EKPO offers bipolar plates made of corrosion-resistant steel with various coating options, citing advantages in cost-efficiency, power density, and cold-start capability. It explains that PEMFC stacks consist of alternating membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) and bipolar plates, interspersed with porous layers for gas distribution and current transfer; the bipolar plate separates the media, distributes them within the stack, ensures uniform cooling, and transfers electric current to adjacent cells.

Brose lists an electric power steering motor as an electronically commutated motor with a power range from 250 to 900 W. The motor has a variable interface for rack, column and pinion steering applications. Brose states the design is free of heavy rare earth magnets and uses a fail-safe system through redundancy. The company adds that the motor complies with ASIL D functional safety requirements and positions it within its chassis and steering drive portfolio.

Brose describes a drive for rear-axle steering based on a market-proven motor concept from ongoing high-volume production. It is available as an axis-parallel or hollow shaft motor, and the hollow shaft drive is described as having a particularly compact design with many integration possibilities. Brose states the drive is suitable for passenger and commercial vehicles, offers a high degree of efficiency, and covers a power range from 350 to 500 W.

Brose lists a drive for electric two-wheelers with a rated continuous power of 4 kW and describes high power density with a low weight of 9.8 kilograms. The company states it is suitable as a mid-range motor and scalable up to a power of 15 kW at 48 V. Brose describes the solution as a polyphase motor with integrated power electronics and states that the integrated power electronics increases range.

Brose describes an electric air conditioning compressor in which a scroll compressor ensures constant flow and quiet, low-vibration operation. The compressor unit is offered for either chemical refrigerant or CO2 and is designed for 48 V electrical system and high-voltage operation. For thermal-management fans, Brose lists a cooling fan module for electronically commutated drives with stable performance up to 120° C, integrated electronics with LIN or PWM interface, and scalability from 300 to 1,200 W, positioned as a benchmark for space and weight in the 600 W performance class.

Brose describes its Smart Cockpit System as drawing on expertise in intelligent access and flexible interior and combining ultra-wideband (UWB) and millimeter-wave radar technologies to build a human-vehicle interface. The company states the system includes a smart digital key that responds to user proximity with synchronized lighting and sound effects to enable keyless entry and locking. By repurposing in-vehicle UWB sensors, Brose also describes enabling occupant detection and automatic tailgate operation, balancing cost and functionality.

Brose states that, as 48-volt architecture becomes a defining trend in new energy vehicle design, it is introducing a suite of 48V system solutions across multiple domains, including door system, seat system, thermal management, and chassis motors. These technologies are described as helping OEMs optimize vehicle electrical systems and improve overall performance and efficiency. Brose also notes that its 48V cooling fan module and window regulator motor have already entered mass production and are featured in new energy vehicle.

Brose describes a compact module that uses a plastic window regulator with a wet-dry room separation function as a module. Brose states the approach enables weight savings of up to 2 kg per vehicle compared to conventional component design. The company adds that integration of interfaces for further components is possible and cites examples such as a loudspeaker, crash sensor, and a door control unit.

Brose states that, together with joint venture Brose Sitech, it is presenting an interior solution covering from seat structures to complete seat. As a leader in high-end seat structures, Brose describes a zero-gravity solution featuring a slim Y-movement mechanism intended for flexible spatial layout and integrated haptic feedback for immersive entertainment. Additional features are listed as including a neck warmer, pneumatic massage, seat heating, and ambient lighting to enhance the in-car experience.

Brose describes an electric oil pump with motor, electronics and pump in a single, compact housing. It uses sensorless and variable oil flow control independent of engine speed, provides immediately available oil pressure, and is intended for use in variable as well as automatic and dual-clutch transmissions; Brose specifies an oil flow of 16.1 l/min. Brose also lists a drive for an auxiliary oil pump that provides constant oil pressure during start-stop and coasting phases, has electrical power of 350 W, uses highly integrated electronics, and can be controlled via LIN, CAN and other communication systems.

Brose states that the Brose Drive S Mag is used as the centerpiece of SRAM’s Eagle Powertrain and describes the mid-mounted motor as having been continuously optimized since its introduction. Brose attributes a magnesium housing to the S Mag and states the torque is 90 Nm. The article characterizes the motor as a compromise between noise, power and volume and describes its qualities as natural handling and barely audible operating noise. Brose also states that, at its e-bike competence center in Berlin, more than 140 employees develop and produce drives used in models from over 30 manufacturers worldwide.

Hirschmann Automotive states that high-voltage components must withstand extreme conditions reliably and safely, including high voltage levels as well as thermal and mechanical loads. The company therefore sets specific requirements, especially for insulation, electromagnetic compatibility, and tightness. It notes that it collaborated with renowned OEMs to develop the Hirschmann Automotive PowerStar (HPS) family, which transmits high electric currents with a voltage up to 1,000 VDC throughout vehicles reliably. The company adds that HPS connectors are used to connect ancillary units such as air-conditioning compressors, converters, and on-board chargers.

Hirschmann Automotive explains that electrification requires an efficient connection of current-carrying lines in high-voltage vehicle electrical systems, and that power increasingly needs to be distributed to two HV units. The company indicates this can be achieved safely with HPS Distributors, and describes the design as extremely compact and highly scalable due to the use of standard components covering a wide range of cross-sections. It lists operating condition U = 1,000 VDC, ambient condition -40°C to +140°C, watertightness IP6K9K and IPX8, and a 360° circumferential shielded area with shield contact resistance < 2 m?.

Hirschmann Automotive presents the PowerStar eLine as a high-voltage connector concept and describes the HPS40-E 4+2 connector system as a solution for on-board charger connections. The company lists characteristics including watertightness according to IP6K9K, integrated interlock, a 360° shielded connection, low shield contact resistance, and high current load at high ambient temperatures. It specifies applications as 3-phase charging, number of pins as 4 (high voltage) + 2 (HVIL optional), and operating conditions of 1,000 VDC, with voltage class B according to ISO 6469-3:2011 (60 VDC < U ? 1,000 VDC).

Hirschmann Automotive states that it develops high-performance cable assemblies for applications in cars with combustion engines and in electrified vehicles, covering low-voltage and high-voltage ranges. The company notes that external loads and kinematic requirements on cable assemblies are tremendous, for example in axle-region cablings and at interfaces between dry and wet areas. It adds that its cable assemblies are designed for these high loads and that the portfolio includes oil-proof wiring harnesses and tight wiring harnesses for wet areas and the engine compartment, equipped with small, vibration-resistant, waterproof connectors or sensor systems. It also states it continuously improves weight and dimensions and minimizes tolerances of cable assemblies.

Hirschmann Automotive characterizes its sensor systems as intelligent, flexible, and reliable for the automotive industry and other vehicle types in the PowerSports category. The company states that, whether for combustion engines or alternative drive technology, its products are suitable for all models and that the sensors use the Hall principle to work contactless, repeatable, and with a high level of precision. It further explains that systems are available as standard versions and customized solutions and include sensor technology, sensor housings, connecting cables, connectors, and magnet assemblies. The company specifies validation for a temperature range from -40°C to +160°C and notes vertical integration from stamped components to overmold to potting.

Hirschmann Automotive states that its Hall speed sensors are suited for demanding environments and produce accurate measurement results. For gearbox speed-sensing without rotation direction detection, the flyer specifies contactless Hall technology and lists benefits including no wear parts and high chemical resistance, as well as high temperature resistance up to 160°C. Technical values shown include signal frequency 1 Hz to 10,000 Hz, air gap 0.2 mm to 5.0 mm, supply voltage 4.5 V to 20.0 V, ESD compatibility ±12 kV, operating temperature tamb -40°C to +160°C, and tightness IP67 / IP6K9K.

Hirschmann Automotive describes its pressfit terminal (HAPT) within a product range intended to ensure reliability under extreme conditions and in highly stressed vehicle areas. The company lists a flexible central web that folds out during the press-in process and states that high spring forces keep the press-fit pin stable in the PCB. It specifies an ambient temperature range of -40°C to +150°C and indicates validation in accordance with DIN EN 60352-5 and various customer standards.

Hirschmann Automotive states that its ring-terminal products combine standard-compliant ring terminals with solutions designed to meet automotive standards. The page lists cable crimp 4–6 mm², material thickness 0.2–3 mm, and screw sizes M3–M5, with further variants on request. Example product-variant entries shown include “Ring Terminal M5 without Iso Crimp 4–6 mm²” with surfaces Sn or Ag and feed “20 mm, cross transport,” and materials such as CuZn37 R350, K88 R520, and CuCrZr R480 (also shown with M3/M4 variants).

Hirschmann Automotive states that the SealStar HMK product range shows its strengths when everything is vibrating in the engine compartment. The company describes the patented HMK range as offering features such as maximum vibration resistance and tightness, and says the high-performance engine contact systems function reliably even at extreme temperatures. It adds that products are offered with an AK receptacle and can be customized automatically. The company further notes that, thanks to a patented insertion process, manual assembly effort is small while the normal contact force is reliable and high.

In its Industrial Components catalogue, Hirschmann Automotive describes wear-free, magnetic Hall sensor systems used for rotation direction detection, rotation angle measurements, and rotation speed detection. The catalogue states that sensors are available with a connection cable (200 or 1,000 mm), with or without an M8 connector, and as 5V or 36V variants. For rotation speed sensors, it specifies contactless and wear-free sensing for rotation speed detection from 0 to 600000 rpm and mentions characteristics such as magnetic pole wheels, a 2- or 3-wire interface, size-optimized design, sealed housing, and various connection options, including use in harsh environments and combination with direction-of-rotation detection.

The company describes thermal management as a critical success factor for electric vehicles, linking long service life, short charging time, and energy density to an efficient battery cooling system. Traditional solutions are described as rigid cooling plates (often aluminum) with embedded coolant channels; manufacturing tolerances can create air gaps and poor thermal conductivity unless thermally conductive pastes are used. The company’s flexible battery cooling replaces the plate with a heat exchanger that adapts to the battery cell shape, enabling direct thermal contact between the heat exchanger and the cell without heat-conducting paste.

The company presents compact precharge resistors for battery connection boxes in electric cars, intended for fast and safe precharging of the DC-link capacitor. Key characteristics include operation up to 1,000 V without additional cooling, high pulse energy with very short charging time, and service life up to 300,000 precharge cycles. A precharge resistor is described as limiting inrush current at high-voltage system switch-on so the DC-link capacitor charges to battery voltage in a controlled manner, reducing the load on capacitors, fuses, and relays. Production is described as IATF 16949, with AEC-Q200-ready testing (temperature change, EMC, moisture resistance, solderability) and 100% end-of-line testing.

The company describes DIScharge resistors as components used to discharge DC-link capacitors after an electric car is switched off, preferably in inverters. The design is described as high-voltage-resistant and non-inductive, enabling different circuit designs. The resistors are characterized as compact and lightweight and are described as suitable for mounting on printed circuit boards; the company also notes the option to integrate multiple resistor types in one package to save size and weight. Listed attributes include high robustness, extensive connection options to heat sinks, vibration and pulse resistance, AEC-Q200 compliance, and customized electrical connections; system voltages up to 1.5 kV are described for inverter use.

Protective and interface coatings are described as specialized coatings for power electronics that inhibit corrosion and improve thermal properties. The company describes full and partial coating technologies designed to extend heat-sink service life, ensure reliable heat dissipation, enable optimum solder connections, and provide electrical insulation while maintaining thermal contact capacity. The coatings are described as suitable for copper, aluminum, and ceramics, as well as sintered, forged, and extruded heat sinks. Quality assurance is described as relying on fully automated processes enabling end-to-end traceability across the process chain.

The company describes soft-magnetic powder-pressed parts for electrical drive systems and traction engines as a route to improved performance, including testing in a prototype engine for the Johammer electric motorcycle. The text describes electric machines using pressed SMC powder (soft-magnetic composite) components that achieve about 30% higher power density than traditional machines. A stated feature of the SMC material is that individual powder particles are coated with an electrically insulating layer. This enables the electric machines to carry magnetic flux in three dimensions, described as key to performance improvement.

For e-bike and e-drive contexts, the company describes developing and producing mechanical components for transmission systems for e-drives, stating that these powder-metal parts meet high load requirements while maintaining smooth and quiet operation. The company also describes intensive development work on axial-flux machines—electric motors with special performance characteristics, especially at low speeds. Soft Magnetic Composite (SMC) is identified as one of the materials used, and the Sinter Group is described as combining materials expertise with application experience in the design and development of e-machines. The text also states that SMC components are produced for a wide range of applications worldwide, for both traction and auxiliary drives.

Highly complex powder-metal parts are described as being integrated in manual, dual-clutch, and automatic transmissions, as well as in all-wheel and hybrid drives, with high-strength, steel-like properties positioned as a cost-effective alternative to conventional forged parts. The page lists sliding sleeves and coupling rings for decoupling mechanisms in all-wheel drives and e-axles, and pressure plates and ball ramp rings for clutch actuation. To achieve high strength, the company describes process development in powder metallurgy, including Densgrad® surface densification to increase strength and wear resistance and Denscal® to enable total part density greater than 7.4 g/cm³.

The company describes a state-of-the-art research and development center for continually improving friction materials and developing new ones.
