Wet- and dry-running clutch and brake systems are described as being tested under different conditions to customer specifications on more than 20 component and system test benches. Laboratory activities are described as developing, testing, and analyzing a broad range of materials—from fiber composites to sintered materials through molybdenum and carbon. The company also frames its friction materials work as contributing to overall efficiency improvements in clutch and brake systems through ongoing development and continuous improvement of existing materials.

Aluminum hydrodynamic bearings are described as combining low weight with good tribological properties and as an attractive solution when weight, friction behavior, and cost efficiency are equally important. The text highlights lightweight suitability for weight-sensitive applications and describes very good emergency running properties, especially with aluminum-tin (AlSn) alloys. The bearings are described as completely lead-free and REACH-compliant and as inexpensive to manufacture, particularly for large quantities. The company also describes offering various aluminum-based bearing systems that can be applied in series projects as well as in individual engineering solutions.

Combination bearings (thrust and journal bearing in one housing) are described as designed for demanding turbomachinery applications with respect to speed, load, and rotor dynamics. Because individual pads can tilt in both radial and axial directions, the design is described as suitable for sliding speeds up to 100 m/s and above; with appropriate oil supply, continuous bearing loads greater than 3 MPa are described as achievable. The page lists sizes up to an inner diameter of 900 mm and materials including steel/babbitt, CuCr/babbitt (to reduce maximum bearing temperatures under extreme conditions), steel/bronze (to allow increased pad temperatures), and CuCr/AlSn40 thrust parts.

From concept to SOP, the company delivers standard and customized charging and power solutions for near-battery functions in the electric powertrain – engineered for high-volume production and global OEM supply. The system portfolio covers onboard charging, power conversion, high-voltage switching, energy distribution, condition monitoring and electrical protection. With deep engineering expertise, a global manufacturing footprint and future-ready system integration, including V2X and grid connectivity, the company enables the electrified mobility of tomorrow.

KOSTAL Electro Mobility, Compleo and vaylens will showcase innovative solutions at the IAA in Munich, from reliable vehicle technology to advanced charging infrastructure and smart software. KOSTAL Electro Mobility is described as a leader in modern power inverters, high-voltage control units and charging technology, ensuring highly efficient charging, reliable charging communication and secure power supply systems in millions of electric and hybrid vehicles worldwide. Compleo provides innovative AC and DC charging stations for private and public charging infrastructure. vaylens delivers intelligent software solutions for charging and billing management.

The charging station uses a weatherproof, corrosion-resistant stainless steel housing to IP54 with mechanical impact resistance IK10 and a lockable door for maintenance access from the front. Electrical data include 3-phase connection with 400 V, input current 342 A, 50 Hz; maximum charging power up to 200 kW, 200–920 V, max. 500 A; efficiency > 97.5% at 500 A and 400 V DC; and integrated overvoltage protection type 1+2+3 with insulation monitoring. Connectivity supports OCPP 1.6 JSON, is prepared for OCPP 2.0 and ISO 15118 PnC, and includes LTE modem, Ethernet and NFC reader.

Each of the eTower's seven 29 kW modules can supply up to 920 volts and 72 amps. The new silicon carbide (SiC) technology is used consistently. The power components with 100% SiC semiconductors enable high switching frequencies and a high power density. This ensures a particularly high efficiency of up to 97.5%. Overall, the modules work in a particularly wide operating range with extremely high efficiency, always with at least 96 per cent at full power. Compleo uses a “dirt channel” so the main air flow is channelled through the heat sink and not through the electronics, enabling laminar air flow inside the modules.

The HV CLASS 3 LSK 8 Ver.1 is described as a water proof sealed connection system with HVIL integration and touch protection, with multiple codings and a header including wire and tabs solution. Listed applications include electric steering and breaking, e-motor, HV-battery, HV climate compressor, inverter and on-board charger (OBC). Technical data include temperature -40 °C to 125 °C, voltage range 600 V @ 5500 m ASL, sealing protection IP67 and IP6K9K, touch protection IPxxB, and current carrying capacity 80 A continuous @ 80 °C / 10 mm² with cable cross-sections 4 mm², 6 mm² and 10 mm².

The portfolio is complemented with the 7th generation stand-alone rain/light sensor which is remarkable for its extremely compact dimensions, allowing it to be incorporated in the base of the mirror and due to its colour it is well harmonized with the windscreen. It also includes the driver-monitoring camera. This camera operates in the interior of the vehicle and checks the driver’s head and eyelid positions, thus detecting his or her attention level. The described system is scalable and includes solar, fogging, and ambient light (HUD) sensors as options, with a uniform black footprint on the windscreen and optimum dimensions for integration at the base of the mirror.

The traditional 12 V wiring harness is increasingly reaching its limits as more electrical devices with higher power consumption are integrated into modern vehicles. 48 V systems are increasingly being used since 2018 (mHEV) in mild hybrid and plug-in hybrid vehicles. 48 V is described as a possible sweet spot between 12 V and High Voltage; existing 12 V applications can shift to 48 V while several HV applications could shift to 48 V as well. Using proven technology, the company’s 14.5 mm connector systems (PLK 14,5) for 48 V applications have been utilized in MHEV applications for over a decade.

The LKS 1,5 oil performance connector is described as sealed, reliable and proven, with over 30 years of experience with sealed performance connectors. It is listed as resistant against high vibrations and aggressive transmission fluids and supports single part traceability. Applications include use inside sealed systems or enclosures and low voltage transfer for power & signal within engine / transmission. Technical data include current carrying capacity 19 A continuous @ 80 °C / 1.0 mm², voltage range 12 V, temperature -40 °C to 130 °C (up to 150 °C short term), and validation according to USCAR 2-7, LV 214 and ISO 16750.

The company’s product range extends from combined steering column switches for compact cars, where proven contact systems are used to switch high-power applications, to tightly integrated high-end steering column modules in premium class vehicles with connection to the vehicle bus. Listed innovation topics include steering angle sensors (contactless, optical or magnetic), rotary coupler (U-turn principle with high data transfer rate and power to heat the steering wheel), and contactless switching with 3D Hall sensor technology. Available functionality includes steering angle sensors for electronic stability control and steer-by-wire, and steering column modules for standard applications up to autonomous driving.

The KOSTAL INVEOR M frequency inverter is described as a drive controller that can be adapted to customer needs thanks to a modular concept. It is available as a three-phase and a single-phase variable frequency drive in five sizes from 0.25 kW to 22 kW. The robust aluminium housing is presented as supporting use in mobile applications, such as in cooling or braking units. Thanks to the motor-mounted design, the INVEOR M does not require a control cabinet or supply cables, which reduces EMC emissions and acquisition costs. Models include a 1-phase device with 230 V or a 3-phase device with 400 V.

Autoneum’s new impact protection plate, made from thermoplastic composite material, shields the battery of electric vehicles from impact, fire and corrosion. The lightweight component contributes to improved energy management and thus to a longer range thanks to its thermal insulation properties. Autoneum states the composite impact protection plate is significantly lighter than metal alternatives and springs back into shape without structural loss or deformation even after repeated exposure to stones and road debris. The plate is based on long-fiber thermoplastic (LFT) technology and has been validated by simulations and vehicle testing at different European OEMs.

Autoneum states the E-Fiber flame shields are based on a composite material made of reinforcing fibers and resin, which are formed into thin layers of one to two millimeters. The heat resistance of up to 1400°C and the mechanical strength of the material increase resistance to high temperatures, hot particle abrasion and gas pressure. Autoneum adds that the fibers provide non-conductive and insulating properties necessary for the battery system’s electrical insulation and thermal safety. The shields can be installed between battery cells and the battery cover or the vehicle floor to increase occupant safety in a battery thermal runaway.

Autoneum describes EV-relevant components including frunks made from Ultra-Silent, which are positioned as particularly light to support higher driving range and lower energy consumption. For e-motor encapsulations, Autoneum states Hybrid-Acoustics PET insulates high-frequency sounds at the source. Autoneum also describes under battery shields made of Ultra-Silent as reducing rolling and pass-by noise and improving battery performance by protecting the cells from heating and cooling. For battery housings, Autoneum states E-Fiber flame shields provide flame protection and electrical insulation and can withstand extreme temperatures, pressure and abrasions.

With underbody systems made of Ultra-Silent, Autoneum describes offering lightweight textile underfloor systems that are up to 50 percent lighter than equivalent plastic components. Underbody systems made of Ultra-Silent are described as having a high degree of impact resistance and optimum stone chip protection. Autoneum states the PET-based, glass-free mono-material is resistant against water and heat and fully recyclable. At the same time, Ultra-Silent absorbs sound and reduces vehicle noise by up to two decibels. Autoneum adds that Ultra-Silent underfloor systems enhance aerodynamics by reducing air resistance, contributing to lower fuel consumption and reduced CO? emissions.

Autoneum describes Propylat as a sustainable, textile and lightweight technology that reduces interior and exterior noise of vehicles. The company states Propylat consists of a mixture of recycled synthetic and natural fibers that are consolidated using thermoplastic binding fibers without adding any further chemical binders. Autoneum adds that, thanks to flexible fiber composition and variable density and thickness of the porous material, properties such as acoustic performance can be tailored to customer requirements. Autoneum lists applications in interior and exterior components such as wheelhouse outer liners, trunk trim, underbody systems and carpets, and it states some variants contain up to 100% recycled fibers.

Autoneum describes Zeta-Light as adding an integrated damping function to fiber-based trim components such as carpets or inner dashes. The company states that, thanks to particle dampers, the system insulates and absorbs airborne noise and reduces low-frequency vibrations of the car body independent of temperature. Autoneum explains that small particles are enclosed in thin non-woven capsules and integrated into the car body side of noise-insulating components; the capsule transfers vibrations to the particles, and damping is achieved through collisions and friction between the particles. Autoneum also states replacing a standard spring-mass system of a trunk floor carpet in an electric vehicle with Zeta-Light can reduce damping-package weight by up to 25% while maintaining acoustic performance.

Autoneum states heatshields are used to provide protection against heat arising in the engine bay and the exhaust system, and it describes these shields as heat-resistant up to 500°C. Heatshields based on Autoneum’s lightweight, fully recyclable RIMIC technology are described as lowering noise emissions as well as protecting against heat. Autoneum attributes the noise reduction to a special perforation developed by the company, which converts airborne sound into thermal energy and absorbs it. Autoneum adds that, using in-house production processes, these perforations are applied only at predefined areas to ensure optimal heat protection and durability.

Autoneum states that, in addition to acoustic absorption of interior (by up to four decibel) and exterior (by up to eight decibel) noise, its fiber-foam engine encapsulation solution enables heat to be stored for long periods after the vehicle has been parked. Autoneum reports that after being switched off for 12 hours, the temperature of an engine with Theta-FiberCell encapsulation is six degrees higher than one without this insulation. Autoneum links this temperature difference to higher engine oil temperature and less internal friction, and it states each six degrees increase in engine oil temperature reduces CO? emissions by three grams per kilometer driven.

Autoneum states it established a new Business Unit Commercial Vehicles to expand its existing truck business and increase revenue and profitability in this vehicle segment. The company says the Business Unit is responsible for global commercial-vehicles business development. Autoneum states the new Business Unit focuses primarily on components for medium and heavy trucks as well as agricultural commercial vehicles. Following the acquisition of Borgers Automotive, Autoneum says it significantly expanded its product and technology portfolio for these vehicle segments. Autoneum adds that, as with its light-vehicle portfolio, its multifunctional systems and components for commercial vehicles are suitable for all drive types, including expected growth in electric models driven by regulation.

Autoneum states Autoneum Pure components are made partially or entirely of recycled materials, which the company says have a significantly better carbon footprint than virgin content. The company describes an approach where industrial textile waste and production leftovers are baled and sold to various industries for reuse, and Autoneum purchases fibers from textile waste and converts them into felt mats. Autoneum also states it uses fibers and filaments containing recycled PET waste to produce fiber mats. Autoneum adds that cut-offs generated during manufacturing can be reclaimed, processed and reused again in production.

After successfully bringing the first series-produced 22 kW on-board charger into the market, BRUSA offers OBC7 as the next generation of an all-in-one charging solution, available in 11 kW and 22 kW versions. The galvanically isolated device targets increased environmental capabilities and operation lifetime across cars and light-, medium- or heavy-duty trucks. The integrated PLC controller supports DC charging control using CCS1 or CCS2 inlets, and vehicle DC contactors can be driven directly. The device includes DC link pre-charge (from 0 V to HV-battery voltage), inlet management, and functional safety and cybersecurity functions according to ISO-26262 and ISO-21434.

With the NLG6 series, BRUSA positions NLG664 as the world’s first series-produced 22 kW charger in the vehicle. The device is specified with an input voltage range three-phase of 360–440 V, maximum three-phase input current (per phase) of 32 A, three-phase charging voltage of 310–430 V, maximum charging current of 60 A, three-phase efficiency of 94%, and weight of 12.0 kg. Galvanic isolation is described as providing electrical safety, while power factor control and correction (PFC) supports reliable operation. The charger can run on single-phase and three-phase sockets, and parallel connection of NLG6 devices enables higher charging capacity for applications such as heavy commercial vehicles.

BSC7xx is described as an HV to LV DC/DC converter for 400 V and 800 V HV-batteries with an HV voltage range of 190–480 V or 350–890 V, LV nominal voltage of 14.0 V or 28.0 V, nominal power (buck) of 3–4 kW, and weighted efficiency >92%. The device lists IP protection IP6K9K and IP6K7, CAN 2.0 communication, water cooling, and weight from 3 to 4 kg. BRUSA describes bidirectionality enabling functions such as DC link pre-charge and HV-battery emergency charging via jump start cable, as well as active discharge. Functional safety and cybersecurity functions are stated as according to ISO-26262 and ISO-21434.

The BSC624-12 V is presented as a bidirectional DC/DC converter with galvanic isolation between the high-voltage and low-voltage circuit, particularly suitable for electric, hybrid and fuel cell vehicles. In buck mode, the 12 V on-board network is supplied with a current of up to 250 A from the high-voltage side. Bidirectional operation is described as enabling additional functions; for example, in fuel cell applications the HV side of the fuel cell circuit can be started up from the 12 V on-board network in boost mode. In step-up operation, the converter is described as enabling emergency charging of the traction battery using a jump start cable.

The WBC is described as a high-performance DC wallbox charger with V2X capability built on BRUSA on-board charger “OBC7” technology. It supports charging up to 30 kW with efficiency >96.5% and specifies THDi at full power <4%. The technical specification lists single-phase input voltage range 85–288 V_RMS, three-phase input voltage range 175–500 V_RMS, maximum input current per phase up to 32/80 A, and communication interface OCPP. Remote connectivity is specified as Wi-Fi (2.40 and 5 GHz), 4G, and Ethernet, and user identification as RFID. The text describes enabling energy flow from vehicle to home or other loads and integration with home energy systems, solar arrays, and grid services.

The BACDC1-G is described as a high-performance, galvanically isolated bidirectional AC/DC conversion system designed for integration into advanced energy systems, enabling energy flow between the AC grid and DC infrastructures. The text lists applications such as fuel cell generators, DC fast charging stations, and electrolyzers, and also mentions battery energy storage systems, DC microgrids, and laboratory environments requiring flexible Power Hardware-in-the-Loop (PHIL) configurations. The system is described as modular with scalable power output, with a wide and scalable voltage range up to 2400 V. Features include customizable power scaled from 22 kW to 720 kW, isolation choice, and peak performance figures of 97% efficiency, ?3% current error, and THDi ?2.5%.

The DMC534 is presented for robust operation in heavy-duty applications including commercial electric vehicles, buses, and industrial machinery. Technical specifications list HV input voltage range for full current output of 250–450 V, continuous current (RMS) 300 A, max. current (RMS) 450 A, typical efficiency 97%, IP protection class IP67, and weight (dry) 12.5 kg, with ambient temperature range -40 to +85 °C and coolant temperature range at inlet -20 to +60 °C. Features include resonant SoftSwing® topology for minimal switching losses and superior EMC properties, a patented Liquid Pin© cooling system, parameterization for third-party motors, and passive interlock.

For the e-Motor HSM1-10.18.13 at 400 V, the technical specifications (with inverter DMC544 at 400 VDC) list nominal speed 6’700 rpm, continuous torque 163 Nm, max. torque 302 Nm, continuous power (acc. S1) 96 kW at 25 °C, continuous power (acc. ECE R85) 103 kW at 25 °C, max. power 214 kW, and max. speed 13’000 rpm, with typical efficiency 96%, IP protection class IP67, and weight (dry) 49.7 kg. The text describes high continuous and peak performance for commercial, high-performance or off-highway vehicles and nearly constant power from nominal to maximum speed. Features include high power density, minimal torque ripple and drag losses, and “intrinsically safe” behavior (induced voltage at max speed and passive inverter < 500 VDC).

The Mercedes-Benz Citaro FuelCELL-Hybrid is described as a bus with a fuel cell hybrid drive and a serial hybrid architecture. The vehicle is described as driven by two electric wheel hub motors on the rear axle, each with a maximum output of 80 kW. The fuel cell is described as the core element, consisting of two modules of 396 individual cells each with a total output of 120 kW. The text states that the DC/DC converter BDC546 from BRUSA is used in all Mercedes-Benz Citaro FuelCELL Hybrids. The application is described as being used in research and funding projects to test the everyday suitability of the fuel cell drive in local public transport.

BRUSA describes its mission as sharing cross-industry expertise and an understanding of holistic systems and products through goal-oriented and tailored solutions for customers. From conception to production and after-sales, the company describes providing solutions consisting of engineering services, products, or a complete system for electrification projects. For e-powertrain kits, BRUSA states it can supply complete e-powertrain kits or parts to complete an existing setup “on land, water and air.” The site also describes “dynamic grid solutions” aimed at grid stability, mentioning ultra fast load balancing and filtering of harmonics enabled by know-how in ultra fast power electronics.

The Rheinmetall DC HV contactor ensures the safe and reliable operation of BEV, PHEV and FCEV vehicles by disconnecting the battery or the DC fast charging plug when not in use or in case of emergency, and it is capable of carrying and breaking high currents bidirectionally. Highlights include best-in-class weight and cost (<300 g), a non-pressurized arc chamber, a sealed design for dust and water protection (IP6K9K), and durability (>300,000 cycles). Technical data list 450–1500 VDC operating voltage, <750 A continuous current, <80 µ? contact resistance, and <10 ms break time under load.

The Rheinmetall Pyrofuse is described as playing a key role in safety in BEV, PHEV and FCEV vehicles by rapidly disconnecting the battery or the DC fast charging plug in critical situations (e.g., vehicle crash or short circuits). Highlights include rapid galvanic separation by a pyrotechnic actuator (<1 ms), gas-tight design (no outburst of conductive and hot gases), high shock resistance (>60 g), and compact, low weight design. Technical data list 450–1500 VDC rated voltage, <750 A rated current, ?40 °C to 85 °C temperature range, <26 µ? resistance, and >50 M? insulation resistance (HV-HV) at 4500 V DC.

Rheinmetall states that its coolant pump portfolio covers low- and high-voltage networks and media ranging from traditional water-glycol mixtures to advanced dielectric fluid. For small electrical coolant pumps, highlights include scalable hydraulic performance, extensive diagnostic functions and an extended lifetime over 40,000 hours, plus a 1- or 3-phase BLDC motor with low noise emission and a modular interface-/mounting concept. The technical data table for 12 V pumps lists flows of 8–20 l/min, pressures of 0.2–0.65 bar, PWM/LIN communication, and ethylene glycol/water 50:50 as medium; operating ranges include ?40 °C up to +80 °C to +125 °C (by type).

Rheinmetall’s electric coolant pump (CWA 2000) is described as crafted to meet high flow requirements with a robust design ensuring a long lifetime, and as standing up well to fuel cell coolants and deionized water. The brochure states that no dynamic seals are used (no aging, high lifetime) and that there is no external leakage to ambient and electronics, supporting safety for the voltage network, e-motor and inverter. It also lists “materials ready for non-conductive fluids,” active or passive HVIL, isolation and dielectric strength to ISO 6469-3, and an integrated inverter for an extremely low EMC level. Stated data include 850 V operating voltage, ?40 °C to +90 °C coolant temperature, 250 lpm flow, 2.5 bar pressure, 2.5 A current consumption, and IP6K9K ingress protection.

Rheinmetall states that its system solution is designed for 400- and 800-volt applications and delivers up to 8 kW nominal cooling capacity and up to 11 kW heating power. In the same text, the heat pump is described as ensuring optimized temperature control of a 72.5 kWh lithium iron phosphate (LFP) battery, with system voltage designed for up to 450 V (HV2) and increaseable to 850 V (HV3) if required. As an active element in thermal management, the system is described as ensuring precise conditioning of the battery and electric engine and also providing air conditioning for the interior, using a connected coolant circuit and “precise and intelligent heat regulation system using water glycol.”

The Rheinmetall Curb Charger is described as offering up to 22 kW charging power and as integrating a 4G modem and Ethernet, with data exchange to backend systems via the certified OCPP 1.6 communication standard and support for over-the-air software updates. The page describes a modular housing design where, via “CurbSwap,” the installed electrical module can be removed from the curb and replaced with a spare module, with a quick connector re-establishing the low-voltage network connection. For all-season operation, the page describes an engineered cooling system with integrated temperature monitoring and a built-in heating system for sub-zero temperatures. It also states encapsulated electronics (IP68) and a sealed socket with water drains; if water accumulates, a water level sensor interrupts charging before the residual current device (RCD) is triggered.

Rheinmetall states that its metallic products are designed and manufactured according to customer-specific requirements, combining performance-optimised materials, high-precision manufacturing and engineering expertise. The page highlights very high flexibility in geometrical design and notes that bores and grooves for hydrodynamic bearings are possible. Listed dimensions include wall thickness 1.5–10 mm, diameter 30–500 mm, and width 10–650 mm, with examples such as half shells and thrust washers. It also lists metallic alloys and composites, mono- and bimetallic solutions, and lead-free materials. Possible coating technologies include PVD (sputter), electroplating, polymer coating, and thermal spraying, with listed layer thickness ranges (e.g., 20 nm–20 µm for PVD and 0.1–2 mm for thermal spraying) and example materials such as CuSnZn, SnCu, Ni, PAI-based polymers with bulking agents, and Cu-based materials.

Rheinmetall lists an exhaust gas recirculation solution characterized as “mono flap,” “high pressure,” and “hot side,” stating that integrated electronics ensure high position accuracy of the flap and that software functionality enhances durability (e.g., soft landing). The actuator is described as optionally glycol cooled, with integrated automatic voltage detection (12/24 V), a brushless DC motor, and a CAN interface with OBD functionality. Technical data on the page include bore diameter 50 mm; maximum EGR flow 500 kg/h (p=350 kPa @ ?p = 3 kPa @ t=700°C); maximum EGR temperature 720 °C; actuation response time <180 ms; internal leakage <12 kg/h (?p = 60 kPa); external leakage <1 l/min (?p = 60 kPa); and durability “20,000 hours or 1,250,000.”

The Oerlikon Skynex® air defence system is described as Rheinmetall’s solution for short-range air defence with an open and modular architecture. The page states that the Oerlikon Skymaster® battle management system is the control node and centrepiece of the system, and that various sensors and effectors can be linked in a modular way to fit mission requirements. It further describes that one or several medium range radars (e.g., Oerlikon X-TAR3D® Tactical Acquisition Radar) provide the air picture consolidated in the control node, from which air targets are assigned to autonomous effectors via the Skymaster network. The page also states that, besides the Oerlikon Revolver Gun® Mk3, effectors such as the Oerlikon Twin Gun® GDF009 TREO, surface-to-air missiles, active and passive electronic warfare means and future high-energy lasers can be integrated to provide layered protection against a wide spectrum of air threats.

Infineon lists FS820R08A6P2LB as a 750 V, 820 A “sixpack” automotive-qualified IGBT module in the HybridPACK™ Drive housing. The device is specified with IGBT EDT2 technology and a pin-fin baseplate cooling concept, and includes long AC power terminals intended to support phase current sensor implementations. Product parameters shown include typical VCE(sat) of 1.1 V at 25 °C and typical diode VF of 1.45 V at 25 °C. The page also highlights low switching losses, low QG and Cres, and junction operation up to 150 °C (175 °C short-time).

Infineon describes its 1200 V CoolSiC™ MOSFET portfolio (discretes and modules) as covering variants with on-resistance from 7 m? down to 1.44 m?. The page states these devices were developed for applications including photovoltaic, energy storage, EV-charging, UPS, and industrial drives, with the goal of enabling more compact and cost-optimized power designs. Listed key characteristics include low switching and conduction losses, a wide gate-source voltage range, maximum Tvjop of 175 °C, and a threshold voltage specification of Vth > 4 V. The same page also links automotive uses such as on-board charging and HV power supply loads (e.g., heater/compressor).

Infineon states that NACS and CCS are not mutually compatible and that supporting both requires extra system effort. The page explains that vehicles typically detect whether the connected charger provides DC or AC; with DC input, a switch routes power directly to the main battery, while with AC input the switch routes power to the on-board battery charger. Infineon notes it supplies semiconductor solutions for these routing switches. The same page describes the OBC function as recharging the high-voltage main battery from AC grids while the car is parked, and links longer BEV/PHEV driving ranges to increased battery capacity and improved efficiency of electric components.

Infineon presents TLE9012DQU as a battery monitoring and balancing IC intended for Li-ion battery packs, including electrified vehicles (MHEV, HEV, PHEV, BEV). The description highlights measurement of cell voltages and temperatures, cell balancing, isolated communication, and extensive diagnostics aimed at safe operation. Listed features include monitoring of up to 12 cells, hot-plugging support, a 16-bit delta-sigma ADC per cell for high-accuracy SoC-related measurement, sensor digital compensation, and a secondary ADC for end-to-end safety filtering. The device also lists temperature inputs for external NTCs plus internal temperature sensors, a 200 mA balance switch, a 2 Mbit/s communication interface, and four GPIO pins for external EEPROM.

Infineon positions its CoolMOS™ 600–800 V N-channel superjunction automotive MOSFETs for multiple high-voltage EV sub-systems. The page explicitly lists on-board chargers, HV-LV DC-DC converters, auxiliary power supplies, insulation monitoring, HV eFuse, and HV eDisconnect among the addressed use cases. It further states that these devices follow a “zero-defect” philosophy and exceed AEC-Q101 automotive quality requirements, while aiming to balance performance with attractive cost points and high delivery reliability for automotive programs.

Infineon describes RASIC™ 77/79 GHz front-end radar sensor ICs as part of the XENSIV™ sensor family, targeting driver assistance functions such as adaptive cruise control and collision warning. The page states these radar front-end solutions can detect and recognize objects at distances up to 250 meters, supporting the sensing capabilities associated with advanced ADAS performance targets (the page references Euro NCAP five-star requirements). Infineon also notes that its 77/79 GHz SiGe RASIC™ chips are positioned as leading devices in the MMIC segment for automotive radar front ends.

Infineon describes BRIGHTLANE™ 88Q5152 as a third-generation secure automotive Ethernet switch: a 9-port device with integrated 1000BASE-T1, 100BASE-T1, and 10BASE-T1S PHYs compliant with relevant IEEE 802.3 standards. The page lists 6 integrated PHYs and details additional interfaces such as multi-speed 10Gb SerDes, a multi-speed 2.5Gb SerDes, RGMII/MII/RMII, and PCIe Gen3 x1. It also specifies a dual-core ARM® R52 CPU operating in lockstep for TSN support (including PTP) and highlights security functions including 802.1AE MACsec, a DoS engine, TCAM-based deep packet inspection, trusted boot, and an embedded hardware security module for secure/encrypted boot and MACsec management.

Infineon describes TLE8888 as containing the key building blocks needed for an ECU in 4-cylinder automotive engine management systems. The page states it integrates communication interfaces, ECU and sensor supply functions, and output drivers for actuators such as solenoids, injectors, relays, and stepper motors, and it emphasizes advanced diagnostic functions for use in modern engine management. Listed feature items include a supply system with microcontroller and sensor supplies plus a standby regulator, 29 power outputs (for inductive loads, half bridges, and ignition), and multiple communication options including direct inputs, a µ-second bus, CAN H, and LIN, alongside protection features such as diagnostics, active clamping, and UV/OV detection.

Infineon’s AURIX™ TC3xx documentation describes the platform as a family of high-performance multi-core microcontrollers built around multiple TriCore™ CPUs, memories, interconnect/arbitration, an interrupt system, DMA, and on-chip peripherals. The text notes the platform is designed for demanding embedded control systems where real-time behavior, computational power, bandwidth, and power consumption must be balanced, and it mentions peripherals such as serial controllers, timer units, and ADCs. Under “platform core target applications,” the same page explicitly includes powertrain engine control for MPI, GDI, DDI, and HCCI, and transmission control functions including CVT, DCT, and AMT.

Infineon describes PrimePACK™ IGBT modules as covering 450 A to 2400 A current classes at 1200 V and 1700 V, with an additional 2300 V offering. The page states these modules are available in half-bridge and chopper configurations and are based on a concept optimized for integration into modern power converters. The cited application examples extend beyond automotive, explicitly including wind and solar converters, energy storage systems (ESS), and transmission and distribution equipment; the page also lists “traction” as another converter domain where PrimePACK™ modules are intended to be integrated.

Batteries are complex electrochemical systems that are influenced by various factors such as temperature, charging cycles and cell differences. A battery management system (BMS) is essential for the safe and efficient control of modern energy storage systems in electric and hybrid vehicles. Preh describes HV-BMS solutions (400V and 800V) including a Battery Management Unit, a Cell Supervising Sensor Unit (monitoring of up to 72 cells per CSSU), and a Current Voltage Sensor, with internal Iso-SPI / daisy-chain communication and vehicle communication via CAN FD. Listed system specifications include operating temperature -40°C to 85°C, IP level IP41, lifetime ?15 years, flame rating (housing & connectors) UL94V0, and maximum voltage endurance 2000V AC.

An on-board charger is described as an integral component of an electric car that enables the vehicle battery to be charged via the power grid, managing conversion of alternating current (AC) into direct current (DC). Preh states its on-board chargers are suitable for both single-phase and three-phase operation and can be used worldwide, regardless of regional grid conditions. The chargers enable bidirectional charging, feeding surplus energy back into the grid with an output of up to 11kW (Vehicle to Grid, V2G), and support Vehicle to Load (V2L) to supply external electrical devices. The same page lists interleaved totem-pole power factor correction supporting up to 22 kW power and an isolated resonant DC/DC converter (CLLC) for stable conversion.

A DC/DC converter is described as transforming the voltage of the high-voltage battery (400V/800V) into the voltage of the vehicle electrical system (12V) and supplying vehicle functions such as control units, lighting and safety systems. Preh states DC DC converters ensure a stable power supply by converting high voltage into required low-voltage levels for 12V and 48V systems, and for the direct supply of drive and charging systems. Preh notes control and protection mechanisms including over/under voltage protection, temperature monitoring and galvanic isolation, supported by innovative topologies and advanced cooling technologies for stable operation under demanding conditions. The converters are described as functionally safe according to ISO 26262 up to ASIL-D and supporting a wide range of communication protocols.

The HV-Booster is described as enabling efficient and powerful charging of electric vehicles with 800V battery systems on 400V DC charging infrastructures. Preh states the innovative HV Charge Pump technology minimizes energy losses and ensures high charging capacity; as an intelligent high-voltage DC/DC converter it connects different charging infrastructures and modern high-voltage batteries so 800V vehicles can charge at globally available 400V stations. Preh describes scalable boost power from 100kW to 150kW and bidirectional charging with up to 11kW, optimized for international charging standards, using state-of-the-art SiC technologies and thermal management. The booster is described as functionally safe in accordance with ISO 26262 up to ASIL-D, with protection mechanisms including fast safety shutdowns (<0.5ms), overcurrent and overvoltage protection.

Preh describes the Combo Box as integrated power electronics where integrating many functions into a single component reduces space requirements and can eliminate external interfaces. Integration is described as reducing unnecessary interconnections and minimizing contact resistance to lower power loss and improve energy efficiency; weight savings are attributed to fewer cables, connectors and housings. Preh also states that fewer individual components mean fewer potential sources of error, and that integrating protection functions (such as overvoltage protection, overcurrent protection and temperature monitoring) on one chip enables more reliable performance. Listed combo examples include “Combo Box 800V Booster & Power Distribution Unit & DC/DC 3,5 kW” and “Combo Box On Board Charger 7,2 kW & DC/DC 3 kW”.

Preh describes automotive control systems (HMI) for the center console (center stacks) where selecting functions on the touch screen provides visual and active haptic feedback. The same page describes combining displays with the haptic advantages of conventional mechanical control elements, including over-the-air updates of new functionalities. A “multimodal control system” is described as a center console with integrated touchpad that controls navigation, heating and air conditioning, while the central display shows the selected function. The touchpad provides haptic feedback, and integrated connectivity software allows passengers to operate functions with a tablet or smartphone via an app, while commands such as engine off/on are reserved for the driver.

Preh states it has been developing and manufacturing climate control systems for more than 30 years. Depending on the automotive manufacturer’s requirements, Preh describes supplying a completely integrated control system—including the climate control software—or supplying only the control surface or only the climate control unit. The page notes challenges in air conditioning control because climate comfort can be perceived differently depending on individual body physiology, and says that, in terms of measurement technology, only an approximation is possible, making engineers’ experience important when designing the system. Preh also describes climate control systems and fanless temperature sensors used millions of times in series vehicles, whether integrated or as a stand-alone solution.

Preh describes a motorized drive lever used in off-highway control consoles as an electrically powered lever that moves in two axes (X/Y) and is fully programmable, combining steering, acceleration and deceleration in a single interface for manual and automated driving. The page states that active configurable haptic feedback can simulate different driving modes, from sensitive control at low speeds to progressive counterpressure at higher driving dynamics. It also states that characteristic curves for steering and driving behavior can be stored and accessed via button inputs in the armrest, and that driving modes, lanes, force curves or stop points can be customized; classic lever behaviors such as automatic reset can be activated or deactivated, and integrating autonomous driving functions is possible.

Management of PrehKeyTec GmbH in Mellrichstadt, Germany, is described as having assumed ownership of the specialist in data input systems from its previous parent company Preh GmbH. As a specialist in innovative data entry systems, PrehKeyTec mainly develops and produces high-end keyboards for point-of-service applications for retail businesses and for banks and airlines. The company is described as having 50 employees throughout the world at three locations, with a headquarters in Mellrichstadt (Germany) and sales operations in France (Cergy-Pontoise) and the U.S.A. (Buffalo Grove, Illinois).

Rosenberger’s extensive portfolio of shielded high-voltage connectors has been developed especially for optimized power transmission in electric vehicles. For Rosenberger, the product development goal is clear: minimum contact resistance plus high power density coupled with excellent EMC performance properties. They meet customer requirements in terms of quality, reliability, performance and price. The shielded HV product line includes extremely compact connection solutions up to 1000 V DC with continuous currents up to 450 A that can be operated over entire product lifetimes. In addition, Rosenberger develops and offers unshielded high-voltage product series (HVU®) such as HVU®48, HVU®50 and HVU®400; current capacity ranges from 60 A and 87.5 A up to 340 A at 1000 V DC.

The Rosenberger HPK system can achieve 280 A (50 mm²) at 85 °C up to 1000 V. With excellent vibration and current capacity performance, HPK connectors are well-suited to high-voltage electric vehicle applications such as the connection between battery, inverter and PDU as well as to e-machine. The range includes 1-, 2- or 3-pole connectors that can be used with copper or aluminum cables in different cable cross sections, with straight and angled cable connectors and corresponding headers available, optional with HVIL and/or SVS (screw locking feature). Listed features include test voltage 3200 V DC, temperature range -40 °C to +140 °C, and IP class (mated) IP6K9K / IPX8 / IPXXD.

Rosenberger HVR®420 compact connectors enable a maximum current capacity of 405 A at a cable cross section of 95 mm² and a working voltage of 1000 V DC. The slide locking mechanism prevents accidental disconnection, and typical applications include charging socket to vehicle batteries (DC). Listed features include a shielded design, test voltage 2500 V DC, creepage ? 7.25 mm and clearance ? 5 mm, IP class mated according to IP6K9K / IPX8 and IP class unmated according to IPXXB. The connector supports cross sections 70 mm² and 95 mm² and is specified with HVIL and mating cycles ? 50.

Unshielded Rosenberger HVU®400 connector series enables a maximum current capacity of 340 A at a cable cross section of 95 mm² and a working voltage of 1000 V DC. HVU®400 cable connectors for cable cross sections of 70 mm² and 95 mm² are available in right angle variants and are mainly used for charging sockets to battery (DC). The unique locking mechanism with special lever and CPA (Connector Position Assurance) allows locking only when mated and prevents accidental unmating. Listed features include creepage ? 13.51 mm, clearance ? 3.46 mm, cross sections 70 mm² and 95 mm², engine vibration SG2 according to LV similar to V1 according to USCAR, and a design without HVIL.

From concept to final delivery, Rosenberger develops and manufactures high-voltage custom components using a component toolkit including PDUs, Y-splitters, busbars and cell module connectors. These tailor-made solutions are designed and configured precisely to the relevant vehicle architecture, allowing ideal combinations of various fuses, relays and other passive and active components required. The HV portfolio also includes busbars or cell module connectors required to link battery modules within a battery pack. Based on a robust butted contact system, Rosenberger offers cell module connectors with integrated flexible tolerance compensation, with systems from 100 to 350 A available, and customer-specific assembly directions, coding variants and cross sections.

Rosenberger H-MTD®, H-MTD®+ and H-MTD®e are differential connector systems up to 20 GHz for high-speed data transmission of up to 56 Gbps, contained in a compact yet robust automotive grade housing. Apart from ensuring high-bitrate data transmission and saving installation space and weight, a further major advantage of this connector system is its modularity, supporting a wide range of Ethernet applications and industry protocols. The system can be used with cables including Shielded Twisted Pair and Unshielded Twisted Pair. Listed features include impedance 100 ?, frequency range DC up to 20 GHz, mating cycles ? 25 (waterproof versions ? 5), and suitability for STP, UTP and SPP cables.

RosenbergerHSD® is described as a homogeneous, impedance-controlled interconnect system addressing high-speed data, low-voltage requirements of real-time automotive applications. This 100 Ohm fully shielded interconnect system utilizes shielded twisted quad cables and features mechanical keying and latching for high connection retention, as well as coding to avoid misuse. The page highlights high data throughput performance while preventing interference from crosstalk and external sources, and positions the cable and PCB connector system for LVDS cameras, USB connections, Ethernet (IEEE 802.3) and Firewire (IEEE 1394) applications. Listed features include frequency range DC up to 6 GHz and high data rates up to 8 Gbps.

Rosenberger has developed compact camera connectors designed for high data rates in LiDAR, radar, and both interior and exterior camera applications including surround view, front, rear, and mirror cameras. These coaxial interfaces include FAKRA, HFM® and RMC® as well as pigtail variants, with housings in metal or plastic and PCB connectors with or without tolerance compensation. Listed features include impedance 50 ?, HFM® frequency range up to 20 GHz, RMC® frequency range up to 9 GHz and FAKRA frequency range up to 6 GHz. For connectors with tolerance compensation, the page lists tolerance compensation in X, Y and Z direction of ±0.5 mm and max. 1.5° tilting angle, engagement force ? 10 N, and mating cycles ? 10.

Rosenberger high-temperature connectors are generally used in engine compartments, boilers and ovens and are suitable for temperatures up to +450 °C. Rosenberger describes know-how in performing thermal and electrical simulations as well as processing high-temperature-proof materials such as ceramics and stainless steel. Different components including cable assemblies, housing connectors and matched antenna systems are developed in close cooperation with customers and partners. Listed features include frequency range up to 2.4 GHz, corrosion and chemical resistant materials, and availability in various design versions such as hermetically sealed connectors.

In an interview on Rosenberger OSI’s site, Samuel Premkumar says that AI has changed data center requirements and that AI clusters require far greater computing power and infrastructure than traditional workloads. He gives an example that a single AI cluster can demand anywhere from 2,500 to 12,000 point-to-point fiber-optic connections, and notes that these installations often need to be completed within a very short window—often 10 to 15 days. He adds that the level of complexity requires highly skilled professionals and that missteps like misconfigured cabling or delays can lead to significant project overruns and financial losses.

Marquardt’s Battery Junction Box serves as an integrated solution for HV battery switching, monitoring and control. With the Battery Management Controller (BMC) onboard, it provides voltage, current and temperature measurements and functions as the interface between the HV battery pack and the vehicle. Marquardt’s modular HV Box houses three modular components: the Battery Junction Box (BJB), Battery Management Controller (BMC) and the HV Sensor. Together, these components deliver a flexible, high-performing EV battery management system designed for easy integration; the HV Sensor is also available as a stand-alone module.

The Cell Module Controller (CMC) is described as a comprehensive, advanced cell monitoring circuit solution that monitors and controls cells in high-voltage electric vehicle and stationary power system batteries to ensure safety, performance and reliability. It detects overcharging and overheating, and battery cells are protected through passive cell balancing of imbalances. The CMC is designed to integrate into automotive and stationary battery systems, enables integration with Cell Contacting Systems (CSS), and supports various cell configurations. No software is required; the Analog Front End (AFE) serves as the communication interface to other ECUs.

Marquardt’s High Voltage Sensor datasheet lists High-Speed CAN (500 kBaud), a withstand voltage of 3.6 kV (HV+ / HV- against vehicle ground and HV+ against HV-), and voltage measurement with a range of -1000 V to 1000 V (6 measurement channels), 0.1 V resolution and 1 kHz sampling rate (ASIL-B). Current measurement is specified at -2000 A to 2000 A with 50 mA resolution and 1 kHz sampling rate (ASIL-D). The datasheet lists operating temperature -40 °C to 85 °C and supply voltage 8–16 V (12 V) or 10–32 V (24 V).

E-Lock Gen 2 is described as a sophisticated yet simple, failure-resistant locking system in a compact, easy-to-integrate package for electric vehicles and charging stations, ensuring compatibility with major charging standards. The datasheet lists IP67 (component level) and IP6K9K (with inlet), manual emergency release, and up to five lock-bolt detection positions. Technical information includes operating temperature range -40 °C to +90 °C, supply voltage 8–16 V (passenger cars), blocking force >80 N at 13 V (and >50 N over all working temperatures), opening/locking time 0.3–0.6 s, and locking pin travel max. 8.2 mm.

Marquardt describes the Interactive Charging Socket (ICS) as an intelligent and holistic approach with a wide range of scalable components. The described module options range “from economy to premium” and include LED illumination scenes, user-friendly HMI controls, automated covers, E-Lock, and other selectable modules. The press text states the system supports integration and adaptation with global inlet variants and offers interfaces for manual and future robot-controlled charging. The ICS is described as an intelligent technology whose features can also be integrated as individual components, for cars, trucks, off-road vehicles, and charging stations.

Marquardt describes its Passive Entry Passive Start (PEPS) system as an advanced vehicle access technology that automatically detects an authorized key fob when it is near the vehicle, enabling a seamless entry and start process that integrates encryption technologies to protect against unauthorized access. The system is described as hands-free: once the fob is detected, the vehicle unlocks automatically, and to start the car the driver presses a start button while the fob remains in a pocket or bag. Key features include dual-frequency authentication using integrated RF and LF communications and customizable antenna configurations (one to four antennas).

In its automotive brochure, Marquardt lists “Start-Stop-systems” as solutions ranging from simple Start-Stop switches to highly integrated systems, with customer-specific operating concepts, individual surface piece designs, robust construction of highest precision and top-quality illumination, described as “according to ASIL D.” The same brochure lists control devices, antennas and door handle sensors with accurate performance, highly integrated features resulting in less installation space, and suitability for different bus systems including CAN, LIN, FlexRay and MOST.

In its off-road vehicle brochure, Marquardt describes a drive authorization system consisting of a control module, key, antenna and start-stop switch, featuring a CAN J1939 interface and dust and water protection to IP67, and described as also suitable for retrofit. The same brochure lists a BLE Gateway and FOB system consisting of a BLE Gateway with CAN J1939 interface and a BLE FOB, with dust and water protection IP67, range up to 50 m, and a standard configuration of two inputs and one output.

Marquardt describes its potentiometer trigger switches with “stepless control” for smooth control of speed and movement, forward and in reverse, and ergonomically designed trigger switches to reduce strain and fatigue. The page lists “high dust protection” with IP50 as standard and IP56 available upon request for consistently smooth trigger action. It also lists customizable options such as a lock-off feature, latching function, three variants of flat cable and caps, and custom trigger caps. For durability, the switches are described as having proven reliability for over 1,000,000 mechanical cycles.

The company develops and produces electrical vehicle heaters in various power and voltage classes for air conditioning passenger compartments and conditioning the batteries of BEVs, PHEVs and FCEVs. It states that customers can be sure all components comply with automotive standards, and that special solutions are as reliable as standard components. The company’s product portfolio includes low- and high-voltage coolant and air heaters as well as interior-placed heaters, mainly used for heating the passenger space and conditioning the high-voltage battery. It uses PTC technology, described as providing intrinsic safety against overheating.

Eberspächer states that it is expanding its portfolio for 800-volt electrical systems with coolant and air heaters and describes these as providing targeted, demand-based heat output for the passenger cabin and battery conditioning, with modular integration into OEM systems. For the coolant heater, the company describes a compact and powerful alternative to classic PTC technology based on thick film technology. It states that the core component is a thick film element applied to a metal plate via a screen-printing process, providing high heat output in minimal installation space, and achieving up to 12 kW output at 800-volt to support battery conditioning.

The company states that lithium batteries are used widely in portable and mobile applications and that reliable battery management systems are necessary to safely use lithium-ion batteries, providing safety and performance benefits. It states that customers rely on Eberspächer Vecture to design and manufacture battery management systems providing real-time monitoring and diagnostics and allowing customized battery settings. The company describes an extensive line of low voltage integrated and high voltage distributed BMS solutions, including standard off-the-shelf, build-to-print and customized solutions. It also states that complimentary power electronics are offered, including DC/DC converters, lithium chargers and cell supervising circuits.

The company describes the Dualtronic Heat Pump as an energy-efficient climate control system for electric vehicles, designed to minimize battery consumption by using an evaporator and condenser to create a reversible air cycle for both cooling and heating. It states that the heat pump transfers heat in or out to reduce electricity usage and preserve battery life, and that it pre-defrosts windows before driving. For extreme cold temperatures, the unit is described as including an electrical PTC heater as a backup to ensure reliable heating. The listed system components are the heat pump unit, e-compressor, external exchanger, chiller, and a central control unit (KanBox).

The company states that its portfolio covers thermal management needs ranging from initial installation or retrofit in recreational vehicles to applications in ambulances and driver’s cabs of special vehicles for construction and agriculture, aiming to guarantee pleasant temperatures in many vehicle types in both cold and hot ambient conditions. It also states that smart connectivity solutions support applications ranging from heating in private RVs to complete fleet management for commercial and special vehicles.

The brochure states that increasingly strict emissions standards have placed growing demands on exhaust systems, and that diesel particulate filters (DPF) or SCR systems could previously often be avoided through internal engine modifications. It states that the situation became more critical with the introduction of EURO 6 in 2013, and that combination systems consisting of diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC), diesel particulate filter (DPF) and selective catalytic reduction (SCR) are now indispensable. It further states that Eberspächer is the technological leader in this product field and that its combination systems fulfill strict exhaust emission standards for particulates, nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons while also having high durability.

The company states that current exhaust systems for hybrid vehicles (plug-in hybrid electric vehicle/PHEV, full hybrid) are similar to those of Otto engines, but that temperatures in the exhaust system drop while driving in electric mode compared with pure combustion operation. It states that innovative technologies from Purem by Eberspächer keep temperatures up and the exhaust system ready for operation. For gasoline-powered internal combustion engines or mild hybrids (MHEV) with 48 V onboard power supply, the company states it relies on proven, high-quality catalytic converters and particulate filters, and that development teams are working on preheating systems to significantly reduce emissions right from the start of the journey.

Purem by Eberspächer states that, in addition to reducing carbon dioxide emissions, further proactive measures are needed to achieve the Paris Climate Agreement’s 1.5-degree target, and that it will present a specially developed Direct Air Capture technology. The press release describes the event focus as capturing CO? from the atmosphere and other sources of emissions, and states that Purem by Eberspächer will present a new Direct Air Capture (DAC) solution at the Carbon Capture Technology World Expo in Hamburg (21 to 23 October 2025), including booth and hall details.

Purem by Eberspächer states that hydrogen-based fuel cell systems are used in a wide range of industry and mobility applications and that water vapor produced as a by-product must be removed. It describes a customized exhaust air system developed using expertise in exhaust technology to address this issue, consisting of several individual components that can be combined into a complete system matching requirements. It states that condensate must be separated from anode and cathode paths to protect the compressor unit and ensure efficient stack operation, and that specially developed water separators are designed for high mass flows by ensuring low back pressure and high separation efficiency. It also describes special silencers for fuel cell systems resistant to high air humidity and water condensate.

High-performance high-voltage batteries are described as being at the heart of electric mobility. To protect them, water and dust must be prevented from entering the battery system, but pressure equalization must be allowed. In case of a sudden pressure increase (e.g. caused by a thermal runaway), the venting unit must reduce this pressure by opening in a controlled manner. Technologies mentioned include a bursting membrane or reclosable valves. Product benefits include permanent pressure equalization due to temperature or altitude differences and emergency venting at a defined overpressure, while being water and dust tight for high-pressure cleaning.

MANN+HUMMEL states that coolant particle filters protect fuel cells, high-voltage battery systems and charging stations from contamination. The company explains that the coolant particle filter removes harmful particles from the cooling circuit and protects the system from pressure loss, wear and overheating; contamination can block narrow cooling channels or cause wear on the coolant pump. Listed product benefits include pressure-loss-optimized filter design, easy integration into the coolant circuit thanks to compact design, and high mechanical stability and chemical resistance over life-time. For charging stations, the page highlights reliable separation of dirt particles from both oil and water glycol mixtures.

MANN+HUMMEL explains that the fan of air-cooled batteries and the power electronics of charging stations are exposed to harmful particles in the air, which leads to wear and tear; if performance drops or the fan fails, the system will overheat. The cooling air particle filter is described as permanently protecting critical components of battery systems and charging stations from particles and water. Product benefits listed include low weight and flexible design, optimization for low pressure loss, prevention of system shutdown by removing water and dust, ensuring a reliable and efficient cooling process, and high filtration efficiency, with variants such as pleated filter elements (including textile add-ons, frames and gaskets).

MANN+HUMMEL states that modern transmissions require efficient oil filters and that this also applies to alternative propulsion systems; the company therefore offers a compact oil filter system for eAxles and hybrid transmissions. Technical features listed include a volume flow range of 10 to 15 l/min and an operating temperature of -30 °C to +130 °C; the pressure-side filter element and oil dryer cartridge are described as service parts. Functional integration includes oil pump, oil reservoir, sensors and thermal management. Product benefits include oil supply for transmission, e-motor and/or battery cooling, sensor-supported oil drying by reducing water content, and temperature-dependent control of oil flow through cooler and bypass.

MANN+HUMMEL notes that an electric charging station’s performance depends heavily on the effectiveness of its cooling system and that DC charging generates significant heat, leading many manufacturers to rely on air cooling. To ensure proper functioning, dust and dirt particles must be prevented from entering the interior of the station; classic filter mats are described as commonly used but having low filtration efficiency, high particle penetration (especially fine dust) and significant pressure loss. Consequences listed include wear and tear, increased maintenance effort, higher risk of failure and greater energy costs. MANN+HUMMEL air filter elements are described as offering enhanced protection of electronic components, highest filtration efficiency, increased cooling capacity, prevention of system shutdowns, and customizable installation concepts.

For liquid-cooled charging stations, MANN+HUMMEL describes IonFree ion exchangers as ensuring greater safety by helping protect electric car charging stations from short circuits. The page lists ion exchange technology ensuring low conductivity of the coolant and a high-quality ion exchange resin enabling superior capacity and purity. It also describes various sizes, installation positions, connection types and orientations to support integration into nearly any installation space, and states that no loss of high-quality coolant occurs because only the filter cartridge needs to be replaced. The article lists example capacities: “IonFree medium capacity” with 820 milliequivalents and “IonFree high capacity” with 1,190 milliequivalents.

MANN+HUMMEL states that multi-stage cabin air filter systems increasingly matter due to air pollution and that multi-stage systems protect vehicle occupants from ultra-fine particles thanks to HEPA filter elements; the portfolio is described as including intelligent systems with sensors to determine air quality inside and around the vehicle, improving air quality while reducing energy consumption. Product benefits listed include a robust, multi-stage cabin air filter system, a HEPA filter for filtration of ultrafine particles (<0.1 ?m), a long life gas adsorption layer with pre-filter function, and glue sealing technology. For a smart cabin air filter system, sensors are described as continuously controlling the system and monitoring air quality, with filters activated only if required to increase lifetime.

MANN+HUMMEL describes a passive brake dust particle filter that uses non-woven metal fibers and is fitted directly to the caliper to retain particle emissions on the brake. The company states that the filter fits in all existing installation spaces and can be adapted to different brake sizes and concepts. Listed product benefits include reducing brake dust emission directly at the source, easy/fast/clean service, and a passive filter system with no energy consumption; use is described as possible for all vehicles and propulsion systems. The page also states that an active version collects brake dust and fine dust at the brake and transports it to a central filter via a vacuum pump.

MANN+HUMMEL states that oil filters remove solid particles from the oil that accumulate in the lubrication circuit due to contamination and wear, and that particle filtration and dirt holding capacity support optimum protection and long service intervals. Engine oil filter systems are described as being available as spin-on oil filters as well as filter modules, with optional integration of functions such as oil cooling and oil pressure and oil temperature measurement. Technical features listed include volume flow range 25 to 70 l/min, separation efficiency 50% at 7 to 20 µm, service interval 2 years and up to 50,000 km, and operating temperature -40 to 150 °C. Product benefits include high dirt holding capacity with minimal pressure loss and availability with high performance MULTIGRADE oil filter media.

MANN+HUMMEL Water & Membrane Solutions describes standardized PureULTRA II UF modules featuring 60, 80, or 107 m² of active filtration area, designed for a wide range of applications including water solutions, seawater desalination, and industrial wastewater treatment, from small to extra-large scale plants. The modules are described as being ideal for standard UF applications using a pressurized, hollow-fiber PVDF membrane, including RO pre-treatment. Listed benefits include requiring minimal pre-treatment, providing low energy consumption, and delivering performance in the face of high total suspended solids (TSS) and presence of FOG.

The company supports customers with tailor-made thermal management solutions to ensure optimal battery temperature control and reliability is achieved. The company designs and manufactures custom OEM line assemblies for battery cooling systems for the EV, BEV, HEV and PHEV OEM markets. The company provides individual solutions with line routings in a wide variety of cross-sections and materials for complex and small installation spaces, and quick connect systems that are robust, space-optimized and error-proof (“Double Lock Feature”). The media-bearing systems are leak-tight and maintenance-free along the entire service life of the vehicle.

Efficient temperature control systems are crucial for the optimal performance and range of hybrid and electric vehicles as well as battery energy storage systems (BESS). Leak tight, maintenance-free, and easy-to-install line and connection systems are essential, and the company’s system solutions meet these requirements. In addition to solutions for thermal management of conventional cooling plate technology, the company offers custom systems for immersion cooling, where the cells are surrounded by an electrically non-conductive coolant. These include precise routing for the smallest and most complex installation spaces and the integration of additional components such as connectors, valves, and sensors.

The company develops and manufactures customized thermal management modules for the individual optimization of cooling circuits, tailored to each model variant of hybrid and electric vehicles. The modules reduce complexity, assembly effort, weight, number of components and line lengths in thermal management. Technical data include line material (hoses and nylon tubes; monolayer and multilayer tubes; plain and corrugated tubes, straight or curved; combinations of different materials) and connection technology using quick connect systems 246 NX, 270/270 DL, 271/271 DL, and 272, plus manifolds and connectors.

Like the company’s quick connect system 270, quick connect system 272 offers space-saving design, high assembly reliability and easy handling in thermal management systems in which couplings are to be used for male connections, e.g. on filigree cooling plates for battery systems. The system achieves functional reliability by means of the auto-latch function, which causes automatic latching of the holding element after a successful connecting operation. Technical data: couplings for the mandrel connection of nylon tubes; plug body material plastic; sizes S6, S10 and S14; working pressure max. 2 bar; temperature range -40 °C to +85 °C.

The company’s temperature sensors detect the temperature in fluid systems, such as thermal management or fuel systems. They can be integrated into the company’s quick connect systems and modules as well as into customer-specific components. Since the measurement is generally carried out directly at the quick connection in the medium, improved accuracy is achieved with shorter response times. No leakages can occur due to the omission of separate lines. The company positions the sensors as an intelligent, rapid, and adaptable solution for monitoring temperature, such as in thermal management lines.

Thermally actuated valves regulate flow in thermal management by opening and closing in response to temperature changes. The company’s thermally actuated valves control temperature-controlled circuits by means of a wax expansion element which expands or contracts because of the temperature of the medium flowing through, thereby opening or closing an outlet. The company offers a customizable number and type of outputs and configurable settings for the stroke of the wax expansion element, because the company manufactures the wax expansion element itself. Technical data list a standard temperature range of -40 °C to +135 °C and materials as plastic (other materials possible).

The company develops and manufactures line and connection technology for fuel systems in trucks, buses, cars, agricultural and construction machinery and stationary industrial engines. The company’s line assemblies consist of single-layer or multi-layer plastic tubes, hoses, connection elements, valves, heat and abrasion protection and mounts. Specialties include line assemblies consisting of single-layer and multi-layer plastic tubes and hoses, quick connect systems according to VOSS standards, SAE J2044 and customer requirements, line and connection systems for particularly tight spaces, and fuel drain line assemblies in common-rail systems (leak-off rails).

The company provides individual systems for heating DEF (Diesel Exhaust Fluid) lines. Features include a balanced technique for safe and efficient DEF line heating performance, safe and simple encapsulation of the electric connections, electrically heated connectors that are air insulated, and reliable sealing intended to prevent heat loss and contamination. The company lists high temperature configuration up to 160°C (long term) and 180°C (short term), plus a laser welding transition between PA tube and heated connector. The systems support 12 and 24 volt applications suitable for PWM control and are designed for extreme environments, especially off-road.

For liquid cooling in battery storage systems, the company describes individual solutions using line routing and function integration. The company lists a large selection of plain tubes for cost-efficient and durable line routing and a large selection of corrugated tubes for maximum flexibility and tolerance compensation, and states that an individual line routing design can be realized. The company specifies inner diameters from 6 to 50 mm for fluidic supply for mobile to stationary storage systems and describes the solution as sustainable due to the use of bio-based materials.

For the BMW iX, the company developed a free-standing center console together with BMW Group designers and interior experts. Rear passengers benefit from more legroom due to the absence of the center tunnel and a console that appears to float above the flat floor, while meeting heightened safety requirements from the modified connection to the vehicle floor. For “Generation E”, the center console was designed with noise reduction in mind; heating and air-conditioning air ducts use a flow- and vibration-optimized design and suitable materials to prevent air noise. The console integrates a 12V socket, USB sockets and wireless charging, and uses recycled plastics and lightweight construction; lighting under the armrest is activated only when the lid is opened.

At Auto Shanghai, the company presented an innovation made of 3D glass for luxury-segment automotive interiors. A novel forming process can be used to create three-dimensional modules of glass that fit seamlessly into cockpit architectures. Glass combines maximum resistance with the properties of a premium surface and can take on haptic operating functions thanks to special grinding techniques. The use of light, color and decorative effects, as well as the possibility to integrate branding elements, provides a wide range of design options. From a sustainability perspective, glass can be separated by type and recycled.

As an exhibit for the Functional Upgrade innovation field, the company showed the Sliding Console, described as a two-part center console on a rail system. It consists of a sliding, multi-adjustable comfort armrest and a generous storage compartment that can also be freely moved. The storage system offers individual partitioning and design options, including ambient lighting or the integration of a safety compartment with privacy shielding. Thanks to flexible positioning, the armrest and storage compartment can be used where they are needed, while freeing up space elsewhere.

In partnership with audio specialist Harman International Industries, the company is working on new audio functions for automotive interiors shown as the Audio Headrest. The headrest with an integrated microphone and speakers aims to provide a trouble-free, individually tailored audio experience for all occupants. In the described use case, drivers receive navigation information or calls directly on the headrest’s loudspeakers and communicate with rear-seat passengers. Noise cancellation is also possible, as is the setting of individual sound and volume profiles for each passenger.

In the Sustainability innovation field, the company focuses on sustainable materials, processes and products, with targets to conserve resources, reduce energy consumption and cut CO2 emissions by at least 50 percent by 2030. On the product side, the company works on lightweight solutions and on the use of sustainable, recyclable materials. One focus is on organic or recycled raw materials made usable for various interior application fields through new production methods. At the trade fair in Shanghai, the company presented a lightweight construction application for air ducts that uses a novel manufacturing process and cellulose-based fiber materials.

The Maximo XT2 is described as a high-end retrofit driver seat available in five equipment variants. It offers fully electric ten-way seat adjustment (height, fore/aft, backrest angle, seat cushion depth and seat cushion angle) and a memory function with three slots. For digitalization, a CAN bus connection allows settings and seat status to be operated or accessed via customer-specific vehicle displays, and optional operation via an ISOBUS terminal is supported using a seat cable with an InCab T-plug. Comfort functions include a massage system (two chambers in the seat and eight chambers in the backrest cushion) and active controlled damping via an electronically controlled shock absorber that adapts within milliseconds.

The MSG297/2900 seat’s suspension system was revised from the ground up to optimize cushioning characteristics, stability and quality. The seat has pneumatic damping and comes as standard with enhanced low-frequency suspension; a new design with greater stiffness increases the maximum driver weight to 150 kg. A new pneumatic module with an insulated compressor reduces the noise associated with damping, and an optimized pneumatic circuit minimizes the risk of leaks. The scissor-type suspension uses innovative kinematics with stable double rollers for zero free play and less friction. A CAN bus connection supports seat adjustment and functional diagnostics with damper wear monitoring via the vehicle’s info display.

The ErgoPlus control pod carrier is described as enabling the driver to adjust the armrests six ways: forward/back, up/down, and tilt left/right. This adaptability is intended for machines where the operator moves hydraulic control levers or joysticks with both hands for hours, for example in excavators. The product is based on a modular platform so it can be used in a wide variety of vehicle classes and applications worldwide. An easy-entry function is also available, in which the door-side armrest can be folded up completely.

The Ubility One portfolio includes Ubility Light, Ubility Air and Ubility Shift for different bus interior zones. Ubility Light can be used in both directions of travel; its ultra-lightweight aluminum frame consists of only five components and is covered with a hard-wearing knitted fabric.
