Ubility Air is a lightweight seat in twin-sheet technology with an outer and inner shell joined to form a highly stable air-cushion structure, intended for medium and longer distances in urban transport. The company states that the double shell of Ubility Air achieves a complete weight of just 4 kg and can be up to 100 percent recyclable thanks to a single-grade material that can be made from recycled materials.

The company’s range of high-quality spare parts is presented as a way to eliminate initial signs of wear on the seat and ensure full functionality for maximum comfort and ergonomics. This approach is described as extending the service life of a GRAMMER driver seat and offering a cost-effective and sustainable alternative to buying a new seat. For identifying the seat model, users are instructed to look at the type plate on the seat, which can be found on the backside of the seat or on the top of the suspension. The flyer also highlights quick and easy replacement of spare parts supported by qualified advice and service from distribution partners.

The company focuses on costs as well as on the numerous technical requirements for electric vehicle battery housings. In this situation, aluminum housings are often used to reduce weight and high costs have to be accepted in the process. With its Tailor Rolled Blanks technology, the company uses steel as the material and is able to significantly reduce the manufacturing costs of battery housings—while maintaining weight neutrality with regard to aluminum and improving crash performance and suitability for mass production at the same time. Moreover, the targeted use of CFRP or GFRP can be used to further adjust the cost/weight ratio to meet customer specifications.

Electric traction batteries and electric motors are core components of the “electric vehicle of the future”, for which efficient temperature control is essential. The company’s roll bonding process delivers thermal management systems characterized by high cooling and heating capacities and strong economy. Roll bonding is the process of rolling two aluminum coils together under controlled temperatures and pressures. By applying a print image beforehand, the coils are prevented from joining locally. The printing image is then mechanically opened from outside the plate and inflated with high pressurized air, which forms out the channels. All customer requirements can be implemented without tools and with maximum design freedom.

The company evolved a well-established roll-bond technology for high-volume cooling plates in automotive battery systems for e-mobility. With roll bonded aluminum cooling plates, the company describes high cost efficiency based on a continuous production process and technological opportunities in cooling channel flexibility, forming opportunities and weld ability of the cooling plates. The company also states that a continuous hot rolling process enables both high quality flat cold plates and complex shaped cooling components with cost savings of up to 20%. The components have high design flexibility and can also be manufactured from high-strength aluminum grades that enable a 100% recycling rate of the products.

The company’s GFRP underbody protection with a sandwich core is described as providing weight savings of more than 10 kg compared to an aluminum solution, while offering protection for the battery case. The company states that all components are manufactured in a fully automated process for high-volume applications. Apart from lightweight, the company highlights benefits including increased vehicle range and payload, better thermal insulation compared to metal, non-conductive and non-corrosive material, as well as improvement of acoustic behavior.

To implement customer-specific requirements, the company modified the conventional manufacturing process for coil springs. With the high-performance process (HPP), the company applies high residual compressive stresses to deep surface layers and describes the result as lightweight springs with increased dynamic strength. The company lists a tension-optimized design, high-tensile steels with corrosion inhibiting properties, various coating systems, and optimum design and assembly and/or joining of the spring pads as key elements of the coil spring system approach.

For tailored tube (MTT) stabilizer bars, the company uses tubes with a constant outer diameter and variable wall thicknesses. The company states that this enables up to 60 percent weight reduction through optimized material utilization compared with a solid stabilizer bar. Automated design optimization and an innovative primary material process are described as making it possible to produce wall thickness gradients that avoid superfluous material in areas subject to low stress.

Engine valve springs are described as sophisticated compression springs due to high dynamic stress and permanently high load cycles. The company states that its valve springs are used in passenger cars, light and heavy commercial vehicles, and motorcycles, and that activities were extended toward small compression springs in injection pumps and transmission applications. The company focuses on operation-optimized valve springs that, with loads as low as possible, cause little friction in the valve train and require minimal installation space. Depending on the application, production technologies are used to achieve tailored fatigue strength for high or low stress cycles.

The company states it has been developing and producing friction damped belt tensioners for combustion engine auxiliary drive mechanisms for over 30 years. Belt tensioner systems are described as usable in mild and full hybrid applications as well as in conventional belt drive systems. For dual arm tensioner systems, the company positions the solution for innovative hybrid applications and lists advantages including reduced belt forces in engines with start–stop belt systems, lower CO? emissions (–0.5% CO?), and reduced installation space requirements, particularly when 48-volt alternators are used.

Mubea Aviation manufactures components, modular elements and assemblies for the aviation industry. The company works steel, aluminum, and titanium using metal forming, machining, surface treatment and assembly processes, and states that composite components and assemblies are also part of the portfolio processed in thermoset prepreg and RTM as well as thermoplastics. It describes manufacturing complex stamped, formed, and drawn components from fine steel, aluminum, and titanium alloys in both single piece and series production. The product portfolio includes complex deep drawn parts, intricate machined parts (blank contour cuts), surface protection via fully automatic coating processes, and sophisticated riveted assemblies and assembly modules.

In a designated engineering stream, the company works on the development of highly stable and fire-proof housings for high-voltage batteries. Such housings are currently primarily manufactured from steel and aluminium; in 2022, the company presented a completely new solution made of plastic that is significantly lighter and includes functional integration, repairability and recyclability. The high-voltage battery housing is made up of five individual modules, each fulfilling functions such as electromagnetic shielding, cooling and ventilation, or fire and impact protection. The housing primarily consists of SMC and glass mat reinforced thermoplastics (GMT).

The company’s modular high-voltage battery housing offers stable protection and meets a wide range of requirements thanks to the combination of different materials. Whether cell carrier, housing cover or tray, each module fulfils specific tasks—from encapsulation and shielding of electromagnetic radiation, cooling and ventilation to impact and fire protection. During development, attention was also paid to improved recyclability through the dismantlability of the individual modules.

Regardless of which battery cell format an e-vehicle manufacturer chooses, the company developed a high-voltage battery housing for cylindrical as well as prismatic cells to ensure stable protection and increased passenger safety. The design (Cell-2-Pack principle) includes three central components; each fulfils tasks such as shielding electromagnetic radiation, encapsulation, cooling, ventilation, and impact and fire protection. In the event of cell failure, a venting concept enables targeted ventilation and particle separation, and extensive tests range from the Bunsen burner test to pyro and venting tests and the final battery cell test.

The underbody is crucial for protecting the battery of the all-electric Audi Q8 e-tron. The thermoplastic composite design features mechanical properties in terms of stability and rigidity; despite dimensions of approx. 2.1 m × 1.4 m, the component has a total weight of around 23 kilograms, almost 7 kilograms lighter than its metal predecessor. For series production, the design combines highly rigid UD tapes with D-LFT to form a thermoplastic sandwich; the UD tapes are heated separately and stacked with the D-LFT compound before the sandwich is placed in the compression mould for a one-shot process.

Using a patented production process, the company manufactures cost-efficient underbody solutions that combine optimum aerodynamics and protection against moisture, noise and heat in a single component. A special achievement is the integration of lightweight LWRT sections in stable D-LFT supports, compacted together in a one-shot process; heat shields or organo sheets can also be processed at the same time. Using the one-shot process, the POLYTEC In-moulded Sound Absorber (PISA), made from acoustic absorber foam, is pressed simultaneously into an underbody and, as a sealed absorber, resists water, fuel, oil and brake fluid.

The company numbers among the innovators of PUR foam acoustic elements and, with its patented one-shot process, has established an industrial standard for engine covers that must possess high levels of noise absorption as well as a perfect surface. Through ongoing further development of the PUR foam process, customer demands relating to acoustic components for battery-driven e-vehicles have also been realised. The company’s solutions absorb noise where it is generated—at the engine, transmission, in the cylinder head cover and at auxiliary units in the powertrain—and thermal insulation functions can improve the energy balance.

The Powertrain Solutions product series incorporates competences for car and commercial vehicle engine compartments. Irrespective of whether cylinder head covers, oil separators, oil pans, air intakes, crankcase ventilation, covers, or fuel cell applications are involved, the company offers solutions focused on materials and engineering. Functional integration is illustrated by the oil pan of the Porsche 911 Carrera: by combining the functions of the air-oil separator, the switch box and the oil lines, the company reduced component complexity and weight, achieving a weight reduction of 36% versus an aluminium predecessor model and cost reductions through design freedom and reworking elimination.

For cleaning crankcase ventilation gases, the company describes an in-house developed, differential pressure controlled oil separator which, in combination with a multi-level suction jet pump, facilitates higher blow-by gas purity in both idling and full load modes. Customers benefit from simplified and more efficient combustion gas cleaning, protection of the turbocharger against soot and reduced engine oil consumption with longer service intervals. The separator is described as freely scalable with higher oil separation performance than disk separators and as a universal plug & play separator for Otto and diesel engines; the pump is described as usable for tank and crankcase ventilation and fuel cells.

The technological focus is described as the processing of polyurethane systems. Components with visual requirements must have a high-quality surface finish with a wide variety of structures, grains or logos, while functionally the components must be designed to be as open-pored or sound-absorbing as possible; additional challenges include complex geometries, fastening systems and strict flame protection requirements. Since 2020, the company has been producing a polyurethane engine cover for a mild hybrid drive of a German car manufacturer in series at its plant in Hörsching, Austria, and it expects to supply more than 600,000 units per year in all performance levels and installation variants.

Reusable plastic transport packaging is described as robust and durable, easy to stack and unload, and (compared to metal or wood systems) as offering low weight and resistance to corrosion and water. The company describes foldable logistics boxes in which every two seconds a transport box leaves its plant in Ebensee; the folding boxes consist of seven individual parts and are fully automatically injected, assembled and provided with an individual QR code so they can be removed ready for dispatch. The foldable side walls are described as optimising transport volume and thus costs.

The transition to hybrid and electric vehicles creates unique challenges for next-generation lithium-ion batteries. Battery housings must prevent the intrusion of dust, dirt, salt and water; withstand impacts and twisting in “skateboard” configurations; and contain potentially dangerous internal thermal events. The company’s high-quality elastomers enable lifetime sealing for battery housings and are designed for manufacturability and serviceability. The gasket concept targets lifetime sealing against intrusion (including immersion and high-pressure water jet tests), ease of assembly and serviceability, and faster production without special surface treatment or additional curing time.

Freudenberg Sealing Technologies offers an optimized sealing material for e-mobility applications as an alternative to PFAS-containing thermoplastic and FKM seals. The press release contrasts thermoplastics (long-chain structures that are not chemically cross-linked and can undergo functionally relevant plastic deformation over time) with elastomers whose molecular chains are chemically cross-linked and react elastically and reversibly. O-rings made from the new elastomer are described as preventing electrolyte from leaking out of the battery cell or impurities from entering, while accommodating that a cell “breathes” as temperature rises toward typical ranges up to 60°C. In customer projects, the new material improved the performance-relevant leakage rate by an order of magnitude (tenfold) versus conventional thermoplastic seals.

Advancement in automotive technologies is pushing cooling and thermal management limits, including rising e-motor power densities and battery systems requiring active thermal management. The company positions distributor valve seals (DVS) as a contributor to replacing numerous switch valves with a multifunctional, multiport valve for intelligent fluid control. When combined with an appropriately designed valve, functional integration of several switch valves is described as possible via a rotating or oscillating valve core. Through this dynamic sealing solution, mass and space reduction is enabled along with elimination of required actuators and unnecessary valves, while sealing coolant fluids with high-performance compounds and supporting complex geometries and serviceability.

In a Battery Show Europe context, the company describes “new benchmarks” in thermal management for e-mobility, including materials aimed at rapid charging and higher battery capacity and designed for integration into customer-specific production processes. It states that leading-edge product lines support vibration-resistant connectors with high offset tolerances, while newly developed materials can both electrically insulate and dissipate heat. The company also reports expanding its portfolio of battery components, citing prismatic battery cell caps, busbar seals, and components for pressure regulation or emergency degassing to enhance efficiency and safety of modern battery systems. Fluid connectors for thermal management are highlighted as helping bridge larger battery capacities and faster charging cycles.

Damaged bearings are described as a common problem in powerful electric motors; bearing currents and electrical erosion can lead to increased noise, vibrations and, in extreme cases, rolling-bearing failure. The company’s electrically conductive nonwoven component, eCON, diverts these currents away from the bearing to help extend service life. Three variants are listed: a standalone grounding system (eCON pure), a combination with a friction-optimized Low-Friction Simmerring® (eCON LFS), or a combination with a gas-lubricated mechanical seal (eCON LEVITEX). The approach is described as combining material and process expertise to achieve high conductivity and, if needed, reliable sealing, and as established in the market since 2015 (including mass production use in the Renault Zoe).

For low-voltage applications, the company emphasizes compact components, tight installation spaces and miniature parts, which place high demands on sealing technology. It reports developing new seals for plug connections, electric pumps and compact air-conditioning compressors to ensure reliable, media-resistant sealing at very small dimensions. Multi-pin connectors are highlighted where numerous pins are housed in tight spaces; sealing challenges are described around impermeability, protection classes (e.g., IP ratings), material compatibility and thermal stress. The company lists sealing concepts such as applying an elastomer layer via chemical adhesion, special elastomer coatings, or plastic-elastomer composite seals to reliably seal smallest geometries, compensate manufacturing tolerances, integrate multiple sealing functions and simplify installation.

The press release frames sophisticated sensors as central to automotive safety and driver assistance systems and notes that many advanced features rely heavily on radar sensors. To address challenges in the radar market, the Freudenberg Business Group, under the direction of Freudenberg Sealing Technologies, initiated the Waveguide Antennas Incubator. It explains that when a radar sensor transmits an electromagnetic signal within a narrow bandwidth, high-precision distance/position measurement and object classification become possible as reflections are received back. Waveguide antennas are described as a key technology where minimizing signal losses within the antenna structure improves resolution and range; they are characterized by precision and robustness. A plastic component with fine wave-conducting structures is described as being manufactured by injection molding and metallized to achieve electrical conductivity.

Freudenberg Sealing Technologies states that its valve stem seals control leak rate for the life of the engine to assure correct guide lubrication while avoiding excessive oil consumption. The seals are described as produced from high-performance materials that increase lifetime and lower wear, and as supplied in a variety of geometries to satisfy different assembly needs. For the “Gas Lip” concept, the text explains that the gas-lip allows lubrication against back-pressure and keeps the oil lip working in a pressure-stable zone; the advantage of a double-lip seal is described as decoupling valve stem seal functions of oil metering and blow-by control.

For data centers, the company positions itself as a sealing partner for liquid cooling, drawing on automotive experience, material knowledge and application know-how. It describes immersion cooling as submerging electronic components in dielectric fluid for efficient heat dissipation and reduced maintenance costs, and states that it supplies sealing solutions for integral components in contact with cooling liquids, including circulation pumps, pipes, busbars, valves, sensors, heat exchangers and pressure relief valves. It also references two-phase immersion cooling (2PIC) as a next step. For direct-to-chip (D2C) cooling, it similarly states that it supplies proven sealing solutions for components such as circulation pumps, pipes, connectors, valves, sensors, heat exchangers and pressure relief valves.

The redundant Power Supply System (rPMS) is described as a solution for supplying safety-related systems in electrified commercial vehicles. The scope includes Electric Power Steering, brake control systems, and the ECUs and sensors required for automated driving. Two independent power-supply circuits are used to ensure system availability, keeping these functions highly available and delivering fail-safe operation in highly automated commercial vehicles.

The eVMC software is described as optimizing the longitudinal dynamics of commercial vehicles with electric powertrains, supporting energy-efficient driving and stable handling. It aims to maximize recuperation during braking by optimizing the existing combined braking (brake-blending) strategy. The motion-control functions are described as being integrable into new e-drive train configurations worldwide, ranging from a central electric motor to multi-motor layouts with axle- or wheel-specific drive for one or more driven axles.

The Electro-Mechanical Braking System (EMBS) is described as technology that can replace traditional safety architectures by enabling full brake-by-wire capability. It is presented as a comprehensive braking solution with a redundant electrical power supply, a redundant brake control unit, and electromechanical brake actuators, plus a built-in parking-brake function. The EMBS technology is positioned to meet the same safety, reliability, and durability standards as the company’s electropneumatic braking systems, while offering advantages in installation space, noise generation, and braking precision.

Hybrid and all-electric commercial vehicles are described as operating multiple components with compressed air, including the brakes, bus door opening/closing mechanisms, and chassis leveling control. The electric screw compressor is positioned as an efficient, quiet, and reliable compressed-air source for these vehicles. Compared with piston compressors commonly used in diesel vehicles, it is described as delivering an above-average air volume and largely eliminating oil carry-over, which reduces wear and extends desiccant-cartridge service life. The design is also described as operating without a crankshaft, benefiting wear and weight.

Electric Power Steering (EPS) is described as a redesigned, electrically supported steering architecture intended to improve energy efficiency and reduce overall costs. Compared with typical hydraulic steering systems, it operates on a power-on-demand basis, consuming power only when the steering angle changes, and a patented solution is cited to help ensure activation without delay. The heart of the system is described as a motor and pump integrated into the steering unit and controlled by an ECU. In regular configurations, EPS can achieve steering forces of up to 8.5 kNm, and it can be combined with an auxiliary hydraulic cylinder for especially high axle loads.

The liquid-cooled, high-performance eBRS brake resistor system is presented as providing an optimized, always-available sustained-action braking function in commercial vehicles with electrified powertrains. The function is described as being permanently available regardless of the battery’s state of charge, helping protect the battery. The fully integrated system is described as comprising a brake resistor, an ECU, and high-performance electronics. It is characterized by high power density and scalability, a favorable weight-to-volume ratio for installation, and braking dynamics intended to balance energy recovery and energy dissipation.

For heavy commercial vehicles, the piston compressor is described as the most common air-compressor design. Depending on the installation space available and the volume of air required for the application, Knorr-Bremse offers models with different stroke volumes, one- or two-cylinder designs, and flange or foot mounting. As a rule, these piston compressors are described as being rigidly connected to the drive motor that powers them.

Pneumatic brake cylinders (actuators) are described as converting compressed-air energy into mechanical energy, providing the force that presses brake pads against braking surfaces during braking. Depending on the application, different types and performance classes are used, including diaphragm cylinders and piston-style cylinders. With a modular cylinder concept, Knorr-Bremse describes robust solutions for many vehicle types and applications while meeting high specifications for functional safety, and notes that modularization has reduced the number of individual components.

Modern rail brake control systems are described as performing complex pneumatic and hydraulic functions. On locomotive-hauled trains, control and relay valves convert pressure from the main air pipe into the pressure required in the brake cylinders. The valves are described as delivering a precisely controlled input of compressed air countless times during every journey, even under extreme operating conditions on the network.
